Original Docket Text: In accordance with Rule 73 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and Local Rule 73.1, the parties are notified that if all parties consent a United States magistrate judge of this court is available to conduct all proceedings in this civil action including a (jury or nonjury) trial and to order the entry of a final judgment. Attached to the Notice is a blank copy of the consent form that should be filled out, signed and filed electronically only if all parties wish to consent. The form may also be accessed at the following link: http://www.uscourts.gov/uscourts/FormsAndFees/Forms/AO085.pdf. You may withhold your consent without adverse substantive consequences. Do NOT return or file the consent unless all parties have signed the consent. (Bowens, Priscilla) (Entered: 03/11/2016)

Original Docket Text: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS re MOTION for Default Judgment 55 . For the reasons stated in the attached R&R, this Court respectfully recommends that plaintiff's motion for default judgment be granted. This Court also recommends that defendant's counterclaims be dismissed for failure to prosecute and plaintiff's motion to dismiss 24 be denied as moot. Any objections to this R&R must be filed with the Honorable Ann M. Donnelly on or before 3/6/2018. Failure to file objections in a timely manner may waive a right to appeal the District Court order. See 28 U.S.C. § 636(b)(1); Fed. R. Civ. P. 6(a), 6(d), 72. Plaintiff shall serve a copy of this Report and Recommendation on the Defendant and file proof of such service in the record. So Ordered by Magistrate Judge Sanket J. Bulsara on 2/20/2018. (Cardenas, Alex) (Entered: 02/20/2018)

Original Docket Text: MEDIATION INSTRUCTIONS for Counsel are available at: https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr-forms. Counsel are to select a mediator, schedule the first mediation session, and file the name of the mediator, date, time and place of the first mediation session via CM/ECF using the event Selection of Mediator. For a list of the EDNY Mediators and their qualifications, see the Court's website at https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr/Mediation/displayAll.cfm. EDNY Mediators are compensated in accordance with EDNY Local Civil Rule 83.8(f)(1)[formerly EDNY Local Civil Rule 83.11(f)(1)]. The Confidentiality Stipulation must be signed at the mediation session by all participants, including the mediator, and sent via email to Robyn_Weinstein@nyed.uscourts.gov. The Confidentiality Stipulation is available at: https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr-forms. Upon completion of the mediation, both parties must submit a Mediation Report which can be found at: https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr-forms. The Mediation Report must be e-mailed to Robyn Weinstein at Robyn_Weinstein@nyed.uscourts.gov within two weeks following mediation session. (Weinstein, Robyn) (Entered: 12/06/2017)

Original Docket Text: In accordance with Rule 73 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and Local Rule 73.1, the parties are notified that if all parties consent a United States magistrate judge of this court is available to conduct all proceedings in this civil action including a (jury or nonjury) trial and to order the entry of a final judgment. Attached to the Notice is a blank copy of the consent form that should be filled out, signed and filed electronically only if all parties wish to consent. The form may also be accessed at the following link: http://www.uscourts.gov/uscourts/FormsAndFees/Forms/AO085.pdf. You may withhold your consent without adverse substantive consequences. Do NOT return or file the consent unless all parties have signed the consent. (Davis, Kimberly) (Entered: 06/01/2016)

Original Docket Text: Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Kiyo A. Matsumoto: Show Cause Hearing held on 7/7/2016. Appearances: Kevin Kehrli for plaintiff; Philip Schatz for defendant. The court heard argument regarding plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction. The parties requested the opportunity to continue settlement discussions and therefore were referred to Magistrate Judge Orenstein for a settlement conference. As set forth on the record, plaintiff's preliminary injunction motion will be held in abeyance pending completion of the settlement conference. The court directed the parties to file a joint letter addressed to Judge Orenstein by 7/11/16 providing their availability for the conference. The parties shall update the court on the status of this action within two days after completing the settlement conference. If the case has not settled, and the parties do not believe that further settlement discussions will be fruitful, the status letter should include a proposed supplemental briefing schedule for the preliminary injunction motion. (Court Reporter: Richard Barry.) (McNulty, John) (Entered: 07/07/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER granting in part and denying in part 47 Motion for Summary Judgment. For the reasons set forth in the attached memorandum & order, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is GRANTED in part and DENIED in part as follows: (1) Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment as to the complaint's fifth claim, for conversion, is DENIED, and the claim is dismissed as duplicative of plaintiff's breach of contract claim; (2) plaintiff's motion for summary judgment as to liability with respect to the complaint's second claim, for breach of contract, is GRANTED, and defendant is liable to plaintiff for its failure to perform under the Note, as well as for attorneys' fees; (3) plaintiff's motion for summary judgment as to damages is DENIED without prejudice to plaintiff's ability to renew its motion upon supplementing the record with the information necessary to calculate plaintiff's actual damages under New York law as set forth in the memorandum and order; (4) plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is DENIED to the extent it seeks an open-ended and unsubstantiated award of attorneys' fees, without prejudice to plaintiff's ability to renew its motion after the issue of damages is resolved and upon supplementing the record with the information necessary to determine the reasonableness of fees sought.Within seven (7) days of entry of this order, the parties shall submit a joint letter (i) indicating what, if any, briefing will be necessary on the issue of damages and (ii) setting forth a proposed schedule for that briefing. Ordered by Judge Kiyo A. Matsumoto on 3/31/2018. (Flores, Diego) (Entered: 03/31/2018)

Original Docket Text: ORDER re 19 MOTION for Default Judgment filed by LG Capital Funding, LLC -- The plaintiff is directed to submit any written materials in support of its request for damages and attorneys' fees, including any affidavits, exhibits, or memoranda of law that the plaintiff wishes me to consider, no later than December 7, 2016, with copies simultaneously provided to the defendant. If the plaintiff wishes to present witnesses in support of its motion, it must also provide a list of all such witnesses. The defendant's default is without prejudice to its right to contest damages at an inquest. If it wishes to do so, it must respond to plaintiff's motion, including all written materials, and provide a list of all witnesses who will testify at an inquest, no later than December 14, 2016. This will be the parties' final opportunity to present evidence or argument to me in support of any request for relief; if the evidence in the record by that deadline fails to establish either liability or any component of the plaintiff's request for relief, I will recommend that the court deny the corresponding portion of the motion rather than allow the plaintiff to cure the defect by filing supplemental proof. Upon reviewing the parties' submissions, I will schedule further proceedings as appropriate. Each party is responsible for arranging, at its own expense, the assistance of a court-certified interpreter for any inquest witness it will present who cannot testify in English. The plaintiff is directed to serve a copy of this order on the defendant and electronically file proof of such service with the court no later than November 23, 2016. Ordered by Magistrate Judge James Orenstein on 11/16/2016. (Klewin, Erin) (Entered: 11/16/2016)

Original Docket Text: Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge James Orenstein:Status Conference held on 1/30/2017. SCHEDULING: The next status conference will be held on March 13, 2017, at 10:00 a.m. SUMMARY: (1) The defendant's counsel of record, Gerald V. Dandeneau, did not appear as required and did not seek to be excused from attending today's conference. Although on December 22, 2016, Mr. Dandeneau expressed an intention to file a motion for leave to withdraw as counsel of record, docket entry 24 , he has not yet filed such a motion and therefore remains obliged to appear for all court conferences in the case unless excused. To minimize the prejudice to his client from its lack of representation at today's proceeding, I respectfully direct Mr. Dandeneau to purchase the minutes of the conference (at his own expense, and not his client's), to provide a copy of that transcript to his client, and to certify compliance with the foregoing directives no later than March 1, 2017. (2) I granted the plaintiff's request to file a motion for contempt sanctions. The plaintiff shall serve its motion papers on the defendant by February 13, 2017; the defendant shall serve its response by February 27, 2017; the plaintiff may serve its reply, and file all motion papers on the docket, by March 6, 2017. (3) I will hear argument on the motion at the next conference scheduled above. A principal or officer of the defendant must appear at that conference in person, along with all counsel of record. (Orenstein, James) (Entered: 01/30/2017)

Original Docket Text: Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge James Orenstein:Status Conference held on 2/23/2017. SCHEDULING: The next status conference will be held on March 13, 2017, at 10:00 a.m. SUMMARY: The defendant's principal, Everett Dickson, ignored the order requiring him to appear at today's conference. He must appear in person at the next conference scheduled above; failure to comply will result in a recommendation that he be adjudged in contempt of this court's lawful authority. Mr. Newton, an attorney licensed to practice in Texas, acknowledged that he contacted the plaintiff directly, without the knowledge or consent of the plaintiff's counsel, to negotiate a settlement with a party he knew to be represented by counsel in this matter. I will afford Mr. Newton the opportunity to submit an affidavit by March 1, 2017, explaining the circumstances of the contact and why he should not be referred to the appropriate disciplinary authorities for an apparent violation of applicable rules of professional responsibility. I denied Mr. Newton's request to seek leave on behalf of Mr. Dickson to appear by telephone at the next conference. I respectfully direct Mr. Dandeneau to provide copies of the attached minute order to Mr. Dickson and to Mr. Newton. (Orenstein, James) (Entered: 02/24/2017)

Original Docket Text: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS re 19 MOTION for Default Judgment filed by LG Capital Funding, LLC. For the reasons set forth in he attached document, I respectfully recommend that the court grant a default judgment against defendant; order the defendant to deliver 1,523,983 shares of its common stock to LG; and order the defendantR to pay LG damages in the amount of $105,794.24 (consisting of $69,965.00 in unpaid principal, $3,438.91 in regular interest, $31,990.33 in default interest, and $400.00 in litigation costs). I direct the plaintiff to serve a copy of the attached Report and Recommendation on the defendant by certified mail and to file proof of service no later than July 31, 2017. Any objections to this Report and Recommendation must be filed no later than August 14, 2017. Failure to file objections within this period designating the particular issues to be reviewed waives the right to appeal the district court's order. Ordered by Magistrate Judge James Orenstein on 7/27/2017. (Orenstein, James) (Entered: 07/27/2017)

I direct the plaintiff to serve a copy of the attached Report and Recommendation on the defendant by certified mail and to file proof of service no later than July 31, 2017. Any objections to this Report and Recommendation must be filed no later than August 14, 2017. Failure to file objections within this period designating the particular issues to be reviewed waives the right to appeal the district court's order. Ordered by Magistrate Judge James Orenstein on 7/27/2017. (Orenstein, James) (Entered: 07/27/2017)

Original Docket Text: ORDER ADOPTING REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS: No objections have been filed to Magistrate Judge Orenstein's July 27, 2017 Report and Recommendation 41 regarding Plaintiff's February 13, 2017 Motion for Contempt 31 . The Court has reviewed the record and the Report and Recommendation for clear error, and, finding none, hereby adopts Magistrate Judge Orenstein's Report and Recommendation in its entirety as the opinion of this Court. Accordingly, the Court GRANTS the Plaintiff's motion for contempt and imposes coercive sanctions on Defendant in the amount of $500.00 per day, which shall begin to accrue on the date that this Order is served on Defendant, unless and until Defendant fully complies with the Injunction Order. Ordered by Judge LaShann DeArcy Hall on 9/29/2017. (Valentin, Winnethka) (Entered: 09/29/2017)

Original Docket Text: In accordance with Rule 73 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and Local Rule 73.1, the parties are notified that if all parties consent a United States magistrate judge of this court is available to conduct all proceedings in this civil action including a (jury or nonjury) trial and to order the entry of a final judgment. Attached to the Notice is a blank copy of the consent form that should be filled out, signed and filed electronically only if all parties wish to consent. The form may also be accessed at the following link: http://www.uscourts.gov/uscourts/FormsAndFees/Forms/AO085.pdf. You may withhold your consent without adverse substantive consequences. Do NOT return or file the consent unless all parties have signed the consent. (Bowens, Priscilla) (Entered: 07/15/2016)

Original Docket Text: MEDIATION INSTRUCTIONS for Counsel are available at: https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr-forms. Counsel are to select a mediator, schedule the first mediation session, and file the name of the mediator, date, time and place of the first mediation session via CM/ECF using the event Selection of Mediator. For a list of the EDNY Mediators and their qualifications, see the Court's website at https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr/Mediation/displayAll.cfm. EDNY Mediators are compensated in accordance with EDNY Local Civil Rule 83.8(f)(1)[formerly EDNY Local Civil Rule 83.11(f)(1)]. The Confidentiality Stipulation must be signed at the mediation session by all participants, including the mediator, and sent via email to Robyn_Weinstein@nyed.uscourts.gov. The Confidentiality Stipulation is available at: https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr-forms. Upon completion of the mediation, both parties must submit a Mediation Report which can be found at: https://www.nyed.uscourts.gov/adr-forms. The Mediation Report must be e-mailed to Robyn Weinstein at Robyn_Weinstein@nyed.uscourts.gov within two weeks following mediation session. (Weinstein, Robyn) (Entered: 10/13/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: The Court hereby schedules a default judgment hearing with the Court on Wednesday, August 16, 2017, at 4 p.m., in Courtroom 1305 in Thurgood Marshall United States Courthouse, 40 Centre Street, New York, New York 10007, at which time the Court will address whether an order should be issued pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 55(b) and Local Civil Rule 55.2. It is further ORDERED that service of a copy of this order, together with plaintiff's motion for default judgment and the papers submitted in support of plaintiff's motion, shall be effected upon defendant by July 21, 2017, and that proof of such service be filed on ECF. It is further ORDERED that any opposition to entry of the foregoing default judgment is due no later than August 4, 2017. (Default Hearing set for 8/16/2017 at 04:00 PM in Courtroom 1305, 40 Centre Street, New York, NY 10007 before Judge Paul A. Engelmayer.) (Signed by Judge Paul A. Original Docket Text: STIPULATION CONSENT TO VACATE JUDGMENT AND WAIVE JURISDICTIONAL DEFENSES: IT IS HEREBY STIPULATED AND CONSENTED by and between the parties and their respective counsel as follows: RCC Ventures, LLC hereby agrees that the default judgment entered on June 1, 2017 (Dkt. 11) be vacated by the clerk of the court; and as further set forth herein. In light of the parties' stipulation regarding vacatur of the certificate of default issued by the Clerk of Court, Dkt. 11, plaintiff's withdrawal of its motion for default judgment, Dkt. 12, and of defendants' agreement to answer the complaint and to waive any potential defenses regarding insufficient service of process, along with the Court's preference for cases to be resolved on the merits, the Court finds good cause under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 55(c) to set aside the entry of default. Accordingly, the Court vacates the certificate of default entered in this case. Additionally, the Court cancels the default judgment hearing scheduled for August 16, 2017 and vacates all deadlines associated with that hearing. Pursuant to the parties' stipulation, defendant is to file an answer to the complaint by August 15, 2017. Counsel for defendant have already entered their appearances. The Clerk of Court is respectfully directed to terminate as moot the motion pending at Dkt. 12. SO ORDERED. (Lattice Biologics, Inc. answer due 8/15/2017.) (Signed by Judge Paul A. Engelmayer on 7/25/2017) (anc) (Entered: 07/25/2017)

Original Docket Text: MEMORANDUM AND OPINION # 91820 that the Beacon Hill dfts' motion to dismiss is disposed of as follows: the motion is granted insofar as : claims based on misrepresentations made prior to April 2002 relating to net asset value and promises to value the funds in good faith are dismissed for failure to plead fraud with particularity; claims based on misstatements and omissions other than claims based on statements made in May and June 2002 due diligence questionnaires, concerning dfts' use of independent marks are dismissed for failure to plead fraud with particularity; sttate law claims by plaintiffs who do not assert a federal securities claim against the Beacon Hill dfts are dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction; the motion is otherwise denied; the motion by Asset Alliance to dismiss is granted to the extent that the aiding and abetting claims, as well the other claims insofar as they are based on misstatements and omissions made prior to April 2002 are dismissed. It is otherwise dismissed. (Signed by Judge Lewis A. Kaplan on 7/5/05) (dle, ) (Entered: 07/07/2005)

Original Docket Text: MEMORANDUM AND OPINION. As the complaint fails to satisfy either PSLRA or Rule 9(b) as to the moving defendants, the Court does not address defendants' remaining arguments for dismissal of the federal securities law claims. The motions of defendants ATC Fund Services Limited and Amsterdam Trust Corp., B.V. to dismiss the federal securities law claims are granted. As plaintiffs already have had an opportunity to amend, dismissal is with prejudice. There being no independent basis of federal jurisdiction over the state law claims, they are dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction (Signed by Judge Lewis A. Kaplan on 7/11/05) (yv, ) (Entered: 07/12/2005)

Original Docket Text: ORDER; that Plaintiffs in these actions 04cv7900 and 05cv10206 have submitted to chambers, but not filed, two motions, each of which seeks a bar order with respect to potential claims "for contribution, indemnification or reimbursement." Each motion recites that such relief would be "[i]n accordance with N.Y. Gen. Oblig. L. § 15-108. There are at least three problems with these motions that are listed in this Order. Finally, plaintiffs have offered no reason for the entry of a bar order if, as their motions imply, the proposed order would do nothing more than declare what in any event would be accomplished through the operation of N.Y. Gen. Oblig. L. § 15- 108. Accordingly, there is nothing before the Court upon which it should act and in any case no sufficient basis has been shown for taking the action requested (Signed by Judge Lewis A. Kaplan on 12/3/08) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:03-cv-02387-LAK, 1:04-cv-07900-LAK(pl) (Entered: 12/03/2008)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: On June 21, 2017, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss. Pursuant to Rule 3.F of this Court's Individual Practices in Civil Cases, on or before June 30, 2017, Plaintiff must notify the Court and its adversary in writing whether (1) it intends to file an amended pleading and when it will do so or (2) it will rely on the pleading being attacked. Plaintiff is on notice that declining to amend its pleadings to timely respond to a fully briefed argument in the Defendants' June 21, 2017 motion to dismiss may well constitute a waiver of the Plaintiff's right to use the amendment process to cure any defects that have been made apparent by the Defendants' briefing. See Loreley Fin. (Jersey) No. 3 Ltd. v. Wells Fargo Sec., LLC., 797 F.3d 160 (2d Cir. 2015) (leaving "unaltered the grounds on which denial of leave to amend has long been held proper, such as undue delay, bad faith, dilatory motive, and futility"). If Plaintiff chooses to amend, Defendants may then (a) file an answer; (b) file a new motion to dismiss; or (c) submit a letter stating that they rely on the initially-filed motion to dismiss. Nothing in this Order alters the time to amend, answer or move provided by the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure or Local Rules. The initial pretrial conference scheduled for September 1, 2017 is adjourned pending resolution of this motion. (Signed by Judge Alison J. Nathan on 6/22/2017) (ras) (Entered: 06/22/2017)

Original Docket Text: NOTICE OF INITIAL PRETRIAL CONFERENCE: This case has been assigned to me for all purposes. It is hereby ORDERED that counsel for all parties appear for an initial pretrial conference with the Court on Friday, May 25, 2018 at 4:00 pm in Courtroom 906 of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse at 40 Foley Square, New York, New York. Counsel are directed to confer with each other prior to the conference regarding settlement and each of the other subjects to be considered at a Fed. R. Civ. P. 16 conference. Additionally, in accordance with the Court's Individual Rules, the parties are hereby ORDERED to ECF file a Proposed Civil Case Management Plan and Scheduling Order no later than seven days prior to the Initial Pretrial Conference. The parties shall use this Court's form Proposed Case Management Plan and Scheduling Order available at the Court's website (http://nysd.uscourts.gov/judge/Nathan). IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that included with the Proposed Civil Case Management Plan, the parties jointly submit a letter, not to exceed five (5) pages, providing the following information in separate paragraphs as set forth in this order. If this case has been settled or otherwise terminated, counsel are not required to appear, provided that a stipulation of discontinuance, voluntary dismissal, or other proof of termination is sent prior to the date of the conference via e-mail to the Orders and Judgment Clerk at the following e-mail address: orders_and_judgments@nysd.uscourts.gov. All pretrial conferences must be attended by the attorney who will serve as principal trial counsel. Any request for adjournment must be ECF filed and submitted pursuant to the Court's Individual Practices; the Court will not entertain requests made less than two business days before the conference. The written submission must (a) specify the reasons for the adjournment, (b) state whether the other parties have consented, and (c) indicate times and dates on succeeding Fridays when all counsel are available. Unless counsel are notified that the conference has been adjourned, it will be held as scheduled. Counsel who have noticed an appearance as of the issuance of this order are directed to notify all other parties' attorneys in this action by serving upon each of them a copy of this order and the Court's Individual Rules (available at the Court's website, http://nysd.uscourts.gov/judge/Nathan) forthwith. If unaware of the identity of counsel for any of the parties, counsel receiving this order must forthwith send a copy of this order and Individual Rules to that party personally. Initial Conference set for 5/25/2018 at 04:00 PM in Courtroom 906, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007 before Judge Alison J. Nathan. (Signed by Judge Alison J. Nathan on 3/19/2018) (rj) (Entered: 03/20/2018)

Original Docket Text: MEMO ENDORSEMENT on 54 LETTER RESPONSE granting 52 Letter Motion for Leave to File Document. ENDORSEMENT: In light of the fact that this case was initiated several months ago and little to no discovery has taken place, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that Defendant's request for leave to file an amended answer is GRANTED. Defendant shall file its amended answer by Friday, January 12, 2018. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED THAT, by Friday, January 12, 2018, the parties shall submit a joint letter indicating (1) whether Plaintiff intends to answer or to move to dismiss Defendant's new counterclaim, and (2) whether the parties wish to file supplemental briefing on the issues raised by the amended complaint, and, if so, proposing a briefing schedule for the supplemental briefing. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge Richard J. Sullivan on 1/5/2018) (anc) Modified on 1/10/2018 (anc). (Entered: 01/08/2018)

Original Docket Text: MEMO ENDORSEMENT on re: 56 LETTER denying without prejudice to renewal 34 Motion for Summary Judgment. ENDORSEMENT: IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that the pending motion for summary judgment is DENIED without prejudice to renewal after the filing of Defendant's amended answer and counterclaims. Upon the filing of Plaintiff's renewed motion for summary judgment, the parties may rely on their prior submissions, along with supplemental submissions that address Defendant's new defenses and counterclaim. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant shall file its amended answer by January 12, 2018; Plaintiff shall file its renewed motion for summary judgment and supplemental brief by February 9, 2018; Defendant shall file its supplemental brief in response by March 2, 2018; and Plaintiff shall file its reply by March 9, 2018. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the parties' supplemental briefs shall not exceed 10 pages, and Plaintiff's reply brief shall not exceed 5 pages. The Clerk of Court is respectfully directed to terminate the motion pending at docket number 34. (Signed by Judge Richard J. Sullivan on 1/11/2018) (ras) Modified on 1/17/2018 (ras). (Entered: 01/11/2018)

Original Docket Text: SCHEDULING ORDER: Defendants shall inform plaintiffs of any objections to plaintiffs' use of depositions taken in In re Currency Conversion Fee Antitrust Litigation, MDL 1409, by 1/31/05. Any amendments to the pleadings, or an application for an amendment, shall be made by 2/1/2005. All additional parties shall be joined by 2/1/2005. Plaintiffs shall file and serve their motion for class certification by 2/15/2005. Defendants shall file and serve their opposition to the motion for class certification by 3/22/2005. Plaintiffs shall file and serve a reply, if any, on the motion for class certification by 4/12/2005. Plaintiffs' expert reports shall be served by 7/15/05. All fact discovery shall be completed by 8/1/2005. Oral argument on the class certification motion is scheduled for 5/13/2005 at 11:00 AM. The parties shall submit a joint letter to the Court concerning the status of the case, and in particular discovery, by 8/15/05. Defendants' expert reports shall be served and filed by 8/15/05. Expert discovery shall be completed by 9/30/05. The trial in this action shall commence on 1/6/06 (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley III on 12/9/04) (yv, ) (Entered: 12/10/2004)

Original Docket Text: ORDER. According to the complaint, this putative class action arises out of defendants' participation in conspiracies alleged in multi-district litigation captioned In re Currency Conversion Fee Antitrust Litigation, MDL 1409. In that action, this Court notified all counsel of relevant facts concerning a potentially disabling judicial conflict of interest. Those disclosures were set forth in a Notice to Counsel, dated 10/31/01, and docketed as docket no. 19 on 1/17/02. A copy of that Notice to Counsel is attached to this Order as Exhibit A. The parties in the MDL action were invited to consider the issue and set forth their respective views on recusal. After consultation with the parties in the MDL action and review of relevant legal authorities, this Court and relevant family members opted out of any potential class and waived any right to possible recovery related to the claims. A copy of the Notice of Docketing, dated 12/13/01 and the Opt-out, Waiver and Release of this Court and relevant family members is attached as Exhibit B. Such opt-outs, waivers and releases remove any financial interest this Court may have in the subject in controversy. The parties are directed to notify this Court by 12/22/04 whether any of them object to this Court presiding over this action (Signed by Judge William H. Original Docket Text: MANDATE of USCA (Certified Copy) USCA Case Number 06-4657-mv. Petitioners seek permission to appeal, pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P.23(f), the district court`s order granting the Respondents` motion for class certification. Upon due consideration, it is ORDERED that the Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(f) petition is DENIED, as the Petitioners failed to make the required showing that the certification order will effectively terminate the litigation and that the district court`s decision is questionable, that the certification order implicates a legal question about which there is a compelling need for immediate resolution, or that special circumstances militate in favor of an immediate appeal. See Sumitomo Copper Litig. v. Credit Lyonnais Rouse, Ltd., 262 F.3d 134, 139-40 (2d Cir. 2001) Thomas Asreen, Acting Clerk USCA. Issued As Mandate: 1/09/2007. (nd) (Entered: 01/29/2007)

Original Docket Text: ORDER. The parties present two disputes: (1) the scope of the record for a proposed class certification motion and possible de-certification motion; and (2) restrictions on the scope of inquiry by Plaintiffs of current and former American Express employees for discovery conducted in the Ross v. Bank of America action... Accordingly, this Court will enter Plaintiffs' proposed scheduling order without modification. With respect to the scope of inquiry of current and former American Express employees by Plaintiffs in Ross v. Bank of America, No. 05 Civ. 7116, Defendant American Express's proposal to limit discovery taken by Plaintiffs pursuant to Paragraphs 3(b) and 3(c) is reasonable. However, this Court finds that American Express's request to restrict discovery taken pursuant to Paragraph 3(d) is not warranted. The parties shall submit a revised order consistent with these rulings by April 28, 2009. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 4/22/09) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP(rjm) (Entered: 04/22/2009)

Original Docket Text: SCHEDULING ORDER. All counsel in this civil action having appeared before the Court for a status conference on March 20, 2009, the following schedule is established on consent of the parties:1. Due dates with respect to the motion to certify the damages class are as follows: (a) Plaintiffs shall file and serve their motion and opening memorandum on or before April 22, 2009.(b) Defendants shall file and serve their opposition on or before May 22, 2009. (c) Plaintiffs shall file and serve a reply, if any, on or before June 17, 2009. 2. Due dates with respect to Defendants' motion to amend their Answer to interpose an additional defense of release based on the settlement in Lipuma v. American Express Co., et al., No. 04-20314-civ (S.D. Fla.) are as follows: (a) Defendants shall file and serve their motion and opening memorandum on or before April 22, 2009. (b) Plaintiffs shall file and serve their opposition on or before May 22, 2009. (c) Defendants shall file and serve a reply on or before June 17, 2009. 3. Defendants are granted leave to move to decertify the injunctive relief class on or before April 22, 2009 without pre-motion letter practice. If Defendants so move to decertify the injunctive relief class, the schedule for briefing the motions to certify the damages class, to amend the Answer, and to decertify the injunctive relief class will be extended concurrently and the due dates shall be: (a) Motion and opening memorandum shall be due on or before April 22, 2009. (b) Oppositions shall be due on or before June 5, 2009. (c) Replies shall be due on or before July 1, 2009. If Defendants otherwise seek to move to decertify the injunctive relief class, they shall do so pursuant to this Court's pre-motion letter practice, unless otherwise ordered. 4. If American Express does not move to decertify the injunction class, the Court shall hear oral argument on class certification and Defendants' amendment to their Answer on 7/30/09, at 11:00am. If American Express moves to decertify the injunction class, the Court shall hear oral argument on class certification of the damages class, decertification of the injunction class and Defendants' amendment to their Answer on 7/30/09, at 11:00am. 5. Any party intending to seek summary judgment shall submit a pre-motion letter to the Court requesting leave to so move on July 17, 2009. The other party shall have ten days to respond. 6. A pre-motion conference regarding summary judgment briefing shall be held on 7/30/09, at 11:00am. during which conference the Court will address setting a briefing schedule and a date for oral argument. 7. The above motions shall be made on the present record, except as allowed by Order of Court for good cause shown or by agreement of the parties. The parties may rely on any materials from now existing fact and expert discovery in MDL 1409 to support their positions. No additional expert reports shall be submitted regarding class certification, without leave of Court for good cause shown or by agreement of the parties. Motions due by 4/22/2009. Responses due by 5/22/2009 Replies due by 6/17/2009. Pre-Motion Conference set for 7/30/2009 at 11:00 AM before Judge William H. Pauley III. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 4/22/09) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP(rjm) (Entered: 04/22/2009)

Original Docket Text: MEMORANDUM AND ORDER In the final analysis, while not perfect, this Settlement with its revamped claims process and the participation of more than 10 million individual claimants embodies Jeremy Bentham's principle of utility to do "the greatest good for the greatest number of people." S.E.C. v. Bear Stearns & Co., 626 F. Supp. 2d 402, 419 (S.D.N.Y. 2009). Given the size and complexity of this multi-district litigation, it was prudent for this Court to have as much information as possible in assessing the fairness and adequacy of the Settlement. This was especially important in view of this Court's intervention to modify the notice and claims process. This Court is convinced that it was worth waiting and any delay was beneficial to the Class. For the foregoing reasons, in the exercise of its informed discretion, this Court grants final approval of the Settlement and grants in part and denies in part Class Counsel's motions for attorney's fees, reimbursement of expenses, and for incentive awards for the class representatives. The parties are directed to submit a final judgment forthwith. SO ORDERED (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 10/22/2009) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP, 1:05-cv-07116-WHP, 1:06-cv-15447-WHP, 1:07-cv-05583-WHP(jmi) (Entered: 10/22/2009)

Original Docket Text: MEMORANDUM AND ORDER. For the reasons set forth in this Memorandum and Order, Plaintiffs' renewed motion for class certification is granted. This Court certifies the following damages class: All Visa, MasterCard and Diners Club general purpose cardholders who used cards issued by any of the Co-Conspiring Banks during the Damages Period from July 22, 2000 to November 8, 2006, and were assessed a foreign transaction fee or surcharge for using such cards to purchase goods and/or services priced in foreign currencies or in foreign countries and who have submitted valid claims, regardless of timeliness in the settlement of In re Currency Conversion Fee Antitrust Litigation, No. 01-MD-1409 (WHP), Master File No. 21-95 (S.D.N.Y.). This Court appoints Robert Ross and Randall Wachsmuth as class representatives. This Court also appoints Merrill G. Davidoff, Esq. and Berger & Montague, P.C. as counsel to the class. Finally, Defendants' motion to amend their answer to raise the defense of release is denied. denying (108) Motion to Amend/Correct ; granting (113) Motion to Certify Class in case 1:04-cv-05723-WHP. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 1/22/10) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP(rjm) (Entered: 01/25/2010)

Original Docket Text: ORDER TRANSFERING THE SETTLEMENT FUNDS TO HUNTINGTON NATIONAL BANK AND AUTHORIZING PAYMENT OF COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH DISTRIBUTION OF THE SETTLEMENT granting (897) MOTION TO APPROVE TRANSFER OF THE SETTLEMENT FUNDS TO THE HUNTINGTON NATIONAL BANK AND THE PAYMENT OF COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE DISTRIBUTION OF SETTLEMENT in case 1:01-md-01409-WHP. Plaintiffs' motion is granted. The Court hereby appoints The Huntington National Bank ("Huntington Bank") to assist with the issuance of refund checks to valid claimants and to manage the settlement fund, consistent with the pricing and terms set forth in the Radetich Affidavit, at G.21-22. The Court Registry Investment System ("CRIS") cannot handle the anticipated volume of transactions. The Clerk of the Court is authorized and directed to draw a check (or multiple checks with a combined total) in the amount of the combined total funds held in CRIS from the following two accounts: (1) the Principal Settlement Fund (CRIS account no. 07-cc-0001-1); and (2) the Notice and Cost Administration Fund (CRIS account no. 07-cc-0001-2) The check(s) should be made payable to: "Foreign Currency Fee Litigation Settlement Fund." Copy forwarded to the Finance Unit via interoffice envelope on 10/5/2011. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 10/5/2011) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP, 1:05-cv-07116-WHP -THK, 1:06-cv-15447-WHP, 1:07-cv-05583-WHP (ft) (Entered: 10/05/2011)

Original Docket Text: ORDER APPROVING DISTRIBUTION OF THE NET SETTLEMENT FUND granting (898) MOTION TO APPROVE DISTRIBUTION OF THE NET SETTLEMENT FUND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE AFFIDAVIT OF EDWARD J. RADETICH, JR., C.P.A. REGARDING CLAIMS ADMINISTRATION in case 1:01-md-01409-WHP. Plaintiffs' motion is granted. The Court approves the proposed allocation of the "net settlement fund" in accordance with the Court-approved Revised Plan of Administration and Distribution (ECF No. 528, Ex. 8), as set forth by the Claims Administrator (Heffler, Radetich & Saitta LLP) in the Radetich Affidavit. The net settlement fund (approximately $275,600,000.00) consists of all funds remaining after payment of the October 22, 2009 (ECF No. 755) awards to the named Plaintiffs ($83,500.00), and awards of attorneys' fees ($51,250,000.00), plus the awarded interest of $47,325.89 (capped as of June 30, 2011) and expenses ($3,708,072.00), and the costs associated with distributing the refund checks ($4,981,582.11 ). Accordingly, the Court authorizes payment of all valid claims from the monies remaining in the net settlement fund for disbursement to the valid claimants, as set forth in the Radetich Affidavit and accompanying exhibits. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 10/5/2011) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP, 1:05-cv-07116-WHP -THK, 1:06-cv-15447-WHP, 1:07-cv-05583-WHP (ft) (Entered: 10/05/2011)

Original Docket Text: ORDER. The following is established: All filings not subject to a claim of privilege and all discovery produced or otherwise originating in Ross, et al. v. Bank of America, N.A. (USA), et al., Docket No. 05-7116, MDL No. 1409, Master File M21-95 ("Ross v. Bank ofAmerica"), Ross, et al. v. American Express, et al., Docket No. 04-5723, MDL No. 1409 ("Ross v. American Express"), and In re Currency Conversion Fee Antitrust Litig., Master File No. M21-95, MDL 1409, including, without limitation, documents, responses to interrogatories and requests for admissions, affidavits, declarations, expert reports, and deposition testimony, shall be made available to Amex, Citi, and Discover, subject to the terms of the April 21, 2009 Stipulated Confidentiality Order in Ross v. Bank of America and the terms of the March 21, 2005 Stipulated Confidentiality Order in Ross v. American Express. The parties' rights are reserved with respect to the admissibility of all evidence and discovery materials and nothing in this Order alters or affects such rights. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 8/3/2012) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP, 1:05-cv-07116-WHP-JCF(rjm) (Entered: 08/03/2012)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: Having reviewed the parties' joint September 10, 2012 letter concerning the filing of motions in limine, this Court orders the following:Each side may submit an omnibus motion in limine with a supporting memorandum of no more than fifty (50) pages. Opposing memoranda may be no longer than fifty (50) pages, and replies no longer than fifteen (15) pages. Each side may raise as many issues within the fifty-page limit as it sees fit. At this time the Court sees no need to schedule additional telephone conferences with the parties in advance of trial. The parties may continue to raise particular issues to the Court by letter and request conferences as appropriate. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 9/20/2012) Copies Sent By Chambers. (ama) (Entered: 09/21/2012)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION AND ORDER CONCERNING THE USE OF EXPERT WITNESSES IN ROSS, ET AL. V. AMERICAN EXPRESS, ET AL., NO. 04-CV-5723 (WHP)(S.D.N.Y.). Plaintiffs and the Amex Defendants hereby stipulate and agree that, subject to any objection under the Federal Rules of Evidence and subject to any Daubert motions, Plaintiffs and the Amex Defendants may rely on the live expert witness testimony at trial of Kenneth G. Elzinga, Orley C. Ashenfelter, Oren Bar-Gill and Robert D. Tollison, experts in the Ross v. BoA matter, and may participate in the examination of those experts at trial as if they were experts in the Ross v. Amex matter. Plaintiffs and the Amex Defendants agree that the scope of their examination of Elzinga, Ashenfelter, Bar-Gill and Tollison will not exceed the scope of those experts' reports and depositions submitted in the Ross v. BoA matter. ENDORSEMENT: So ordered. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 10/19/2012) (rjm) (Entered: 10/23/2012)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION AND ORDER CONCERNING THE EXCLUSION OF PERCIPIENT WITNESSES: Plaintiffs, American Express, Citibank and Discover are entitled to designate a single party representative each who shall not be excluded from the courtroom at any time during trial on the basis of his or her status as a percipient witness. Nothing in P1 above is intended to prohibit any party from having additional party representatives who are not percipient witnesses present in the courtroom during trial either in addition to the designated party representative or as an alternate for the designated party representative in the event the designated party representative is unavailable for any reason. With the exception of party representatives designated pursuant to P1 above, every other percipient witness shall be excluded from the courtroom until after completion of his or her testimony. During such time as a percipient witness is excluded from the courtroom, he or she shall also be prohibited from reading any portions of court transcripts, or summaries thereof, documenting proceedings in the above-captioned matters. Nothing in this Stipulation and Order shall be interpreted to exclude from the courtroom any expert witness testifying on behalf of any party. Nothing in this Stipulation and Order shall be interpreted to limit the Court's inherent authority to exclude any individual from the courtroom on grounds other than that individual's status as a percipient witness. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 12/18/2012) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP, 1:05-cv-07116-WHP-JCF(ft) (Entered: 12/19/2012)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: All parties having appeared for a final pre-trial conference on December 14, 2012, this Court establishes the following schedule. This Court will not fix time limits for the presentation of evidence. The Court has allotted four weeks for the trial of this action and will work with the parties to complete the trial during that time period. But if the case is not completed in that time frame, the presentations will be interrupted to accommodate at least one criminal trial beginning on February 4,2013. Each party may submit an omnibus motion in limine, not to exceed 35 pages, addressing significant objections to important evidence by December 21,2012. Opposition papers shall be filed by December 28,2012. The parties are directed to provide 48 hours advance notice of any witness they intend to call at trial. Notice for witnesses expected to be called on Mondays will be provided no later than the preceding Friday morning.This Court declines the Plaintiffs' proposal that portions of witness testimony relating to background information, document identification, or other qualifying evidence bereceived in written form. The parties are encouraged to stipulate to undisputed facts and the admissibility of exhibits. All parties are directed to appear for a conference to discuss remaining pre-trial issues on January 4,2013 at 2:00 p.m. The parties are directed to re-file their motions in limine, Daubert motions andsupporting papers electronically in unredacted form. The Clerk of the Court is directed to terminate the motions pending at ECF No.' s 419,420,421,423,426,432,433,438, and 440. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 12/21/2012) (ago) (Entered: 12/21/2012)

Original Docket Text: ORDER APPROVING DISTRIBUTION OF THE AGGREGATE NET SETTLEMENT FUND. This Court having reviewed Plaintiffs' Motion to Approve the Distribution of the Aggregate Net Settlement Fund in Accordance with the March 8, 2013 Affidavit of Edward J. Radetich, Jr., C.P.A. ("Radetich Affidavit"), the Radetich Affidavit, and all supporting exhibits submitted with respect thereto, it is ORDERED that Plaintiffs' motion is GRANTED. IT IS HEREBY FURTHER ORDERED as follows: 1. The Court approves the proposed allocation of the Aggregate Net Settlement Fund in accordance with the Court-approved Allocation Plan in Ross v. American Express Co. ("AMEX") (AMEX Dkt. No. 214) and the Court-approved CCF I Residual Allocation Plan (Ex. 1 to the April 20, 2012 Declaration of Nicholas Urban) (jointly, the "Plans"), as set forth by the Claims Administrator (Heffler, Radetich & Saitta LLP) in the Radetich Affidavit. The Aggregate Net Settlement Fund (approximately $84,831,534.18) consists of (a) the amount remaining in the AMEX settlement fund after the Court-ordered awards to the named Plaintiffs, attorneys' fees and expenses, and notice, settlement administration and distribution expenses, and a $2.5 million reserve fund, see paragraph 3 below CAMEX Net Settlement Fund"), and (b) the Residual CCF I Settlement Fund (consisting of funds remaining in the Foreign Currency Fee Litigation Settlement Fund as of January 15, 2013, minus additional, post-fee petition, Court-approved costs, addressed in paragraph 2 below, and a $2.5 million reserve fund, addressed in paragraph 3 below). 2. The Court approves the reimbursement of $187,090.22 of post-fee petition CCF I costs to Plaintiffs' counsel. 3. The Court approves the creation of a $5 million reserve fund to cover potential reissues of checks to claimants and any CCF I checks which clear after January 15, 2013, to be allocated in the amount of $2.5 million each to the AMEX Net Settlement Fund and to the Residual CCF I Settlement Fund. 4. The Court finds that the Claims Administrator's methodology for calculating the pro-rata distributions, as set forth in the Radetich Affidavit, complies with: (a) the Plans, previously approved by the Court in its Orders dated April 30, 2012 (CCF I Dkt. Nos. 946 and 947); and (b) the requirements of due process, with all claimants having had a full and fair opportunity to present their claims and to be heard in connection with the processing and auditing thereof. 5. Accordingly, the Court authorizes payment of claims from the monies remaining in the Aggregate Net Settlement Fund for disbursement to the claimants, as set forth in the Radetich Affidavit and accompanying exhibits. 6. Plaintiffs' Lead Counsel are hereby authorized to distribute the Aggregate Net Settlement Fund in accordance with this Order and the findings, conclusions and determinations set forth in the Radetich Affidavit. 7. Without affecting the finality of the AMEX Order and Final Judgment Approving Settlement (CCF I Dkt. No. 948) or the CCF I Final Judgment and Order of Dismissal (CCF I Dkt. No. 763) or this Order in any respect, this Court reserves jurisdiction over any matters related to or ancillary to this Order. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 4/16/2013). Original Docket Text: OPINION & ORDER #104191 : These actions are the latest installment in multidistrict litigation that spanned more than a decade and raised a spate of novel issues. They offer a cautionary lesson to all lawyers who labor under inexorable pressure to generate new business. When outside counsel convene meetings of competitors in the hope of propelling themselves to the forefront of an emerging trend-in this case, class-action-barring consumer arbitration agreements-they do so at their professional peril. When the first meeting convened, only two defendants had class-action-barring arbitration clauses in their card member agreements. By the time the last meeting concluded, all ten of the Issuing Banks, accounting for approximately 87% of all credit card transactions in the United States, had adopted class-action-barring arbitration clauses in their card member agreements. It was only by a slender reed that Plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that the lawyers who organized these meetings had spawned a Sherman Act conspiracy among their clients. In retrospect, the Issuing Banks' short-term goal of lowering litigation costs eluded them. Undoubtedly, retaining some of the most esteemed antitrust lawyers in the nation to counter the extraordinary talents of Plaintiffs' counsel imposed a significant burden on the Issuing Banks. Only the passage of time will reveal whether the Issuing Banks' longer-term goal of avoiding the expense of class action lawsuits can be achieved. For the foregoing reasons, this Court grants judgment to the Defendants dismissing Plaintiffs' antitrust claims in this action for injunctive relief invalidating the class-action-barring arbitration clauses. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 4/10/2014) (mro) Modified on 4/11/2014 (ca). (Entered: 04/10/2014)

Original Docket Text: JUDGMENT: The issues in the above entitled actions having been brought on for a joint trial before the Honorable William H. Pauley, III, United States District Judge, without a jury, commencing on January 7, 2013, and concluding on February 7, 2013, and closing arguments having been held on May 2, 2013, and the Court thereafter, having rendered its Opinion and Order (Doc.# 366 in case no. 04cv5723, and Doc.# 565 in case no. 05cv7116), dated April 10, 2014, granting judgment in favor of the Defendants, and dismissing Plaintiffs' antitrust claims in these actions for injunctive relief invalidating the class-action-barring arbitration clauses, it is, ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED: That for the reasons stated in the Court's Opinion and Order dated April 10, 2014 (Doc.# 366 in case no. 04cv5723, and Doc. # 565 in case no. 05cv7116), judgment is entered in favor of the Defendants, and the Plaintiffs' antitrust claims in these actions for injunctive relief invalidating the class-action-barring arbitration clauses are dismissed. Original Docket Text: ORDER APPROVING THE FOURTH AND FINAL DISTRIBUTION PLAN AND AWARDING FEES AND EXPENSES granting (378) Motion to Approve in case 1:04-cv-05723-WHP; granting (998) Motion to Approve in case 1:01-md-01409-WHP. The Court finds that the proposed plan of allocation (the "Fourth Distribution Plan"), as set forth in the Affidavit of Edward J. Radetich, Jr., C.P.A. Regarding Status and Proposed Re-Distribution of the Remaining Net Settlement Fund ("September 2015 Radetich Affidavit"), is fair and reasonable. The Court approves the Fourth Distribution Plan and orders that it be effected, and retains jurisdiction to supervise the implementation and effectuation of the Fourth Distribution Plan and this Order. The remaining Net Settlement Fund (approximately $908,926.91) consists of $923,969.96 from uncashed checks from the November 2014 distribution (the "Third Distribution"); plus $284,196.79, representing the unused portion of the reserve funds established m connection with the Third Distribution; minus $100,917.48 (consisting of $64,817.48 of previously incurred but not yet paid administrative costs, and $36,100.00 of estimated administrative costs for the proposed Fourth Distribution (i.e., printing, postage, bank clearing services and other administrative services)), a $150,000 reserve fund, and $48,322.36, representing Lead Counsel's request in Ross v. American Express Co. ("AMEX"), No. 04-CV-5723 (S.D.N.Y.), for a supplemental award of attorneys' fees and unreimbursed expenses. The Court approves the creation of a $150,000 reserve fund to cover potential reissues of checks to claimants and any Third Distribution checks which clear after August 31, 2015. However, the Court further directs that any request for a check to be reissued made after September 30, 2015 shall be rejected. The Court awards to AMEX Lead Counsel reasonable and appropriate attorneys' fees in the amount of $47,328.50, for work on settlement administration in the AMEX case. The Court also approves the reimbursement of $993.86 of AMEX expenses. The Court authorizes payment of claims from the remaining Net Settlement Fund for disbursement to the eligible claimants, as set forth in the September 2015 Radetich Affidavit and accompanying exhibits. Plaintiffs' Lead Counsel are hereby authorized to distribute the remaining Net Settlement Fund in accordance with this Order and the findings, conclusions and determinations set forth in the September 2015 Radetich Affidavit. The Court directs that the distribution checks issued pursuant to the Fourth Distribution Plan shall bear the notation "Void after 45 Days," and that no check shall be negotiated more than 120 days (four months) from the date of this Order. Checks that are not negotiated by the payee during this period will be void, and the accounts from which the funds would be drawn when a check is presented to a bank will be closed on the 121 st day. The Court directs that Lead Counsel are authorized to distribute the following percentages of any balance remaining on the 121 st day from the date of this Order to the following non-profit organizations: (1) 42% to Community Legal Services of Philadelphia, and (2) 58% to JDRF. The Claims Administrator may destroy all claim files within 300 days from the date of this Order. This Court reserves jurisdiction over any matters related to or ancillary to this Order. (Signed by Judge William H. Pauley, III on 12/21/2015) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:01-md-01409-WHP, 1:04-cv-05723-WHP (mro) (Entered: 12/21/2015)

STANDING ORDER IN RE PILOT PROJECT REGARDING CASE MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES FOR COMPLEX CIVIL CASES IN THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK (See M-10-468 Order filed November 1, 2011). This case is hereby designated for inclusion in the Pilot Project Regarding Case Management Techniques for Complex Civil Cases in the Southern District of New York (the Pilot Project), unless the judge to whom this case is assigned determines otherwise. This case is designated for inclusion in the Pilot Project because it is a class action, an MDL action, or is in one of the following Nature of Suit categories: 160, 245, 315, 355, 365, 385, 410, 830, 840, 850, 893, or 950. The presiding judge in a case that does not otherwise qualify for inclusion in the Pilot Project may nevertheless designate the case for inclusion in the Pilot Project by issuing an order directing that the case be included in the Pilot Project. The description of the Pilot Project, including procedures to be followed, is attached to this Order. (Signed by Judge Loretta A. Preska on 10/31/2011) (jom) (Entered: 09/25/2013)

Original Docket Text: ORDER. By letter of October 9, 2013, plaintiff National Credit Union Administration Board ("NCUA") requests that one of these nine actions -- the one brought against lead defendant Morgan Stanley & Co. ("Morgan Stanley") -- be designated the lead case for purposes of briefing any motion to dismiss. For the following reasons, the application is granted (See Order). The defendants in 13 Civ. 6705 must answer or otherwise respond to the complaint by November 13, 2013. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the time to answer in each of the other seven actions is stayed pending further order of this Court. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the motion by Goldman, Sachs & Co. et al. in 13 Civ. 6721 to compel arbitration shall be filed by November 13, 2013. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the conference of November 14, 2013 will proceed as scheduled in all actions except 13 Civ. 6730 (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 10/23/2013) (gr) (Entered: 10/23/2013)

Original Docket Text: ORDER. On February 5, 2014, Wachovia Capital Markets, n/k/a Wells Fargo Securities (Wells Fargo), moved to dismiss the action brought by the National Credit Union Administration Board (NCUA). NCUA v. Wachovia Capital Markets, LLC n/k/a Wells Fargo Secs., LLC, 13 Civ. 6719 (DLC). For the reasons set forth in this Order, the motion is stayed pending further order of this Court.On February 6, Wells Fargo filed a motion to dismiss. The MDL Panel has not, however, ruled on the motion to transfer. It had originally scheduled a hearing date on the motion for January 31, 2014. But that date was rescheduled to February 7 due to inclement weather in the New Orleans area. Accordingly, it is hereby ORDERED that Wells Fargos February 6, 2014 motion to dismiss, filed in 13 Civ. 6719, is stayed pending further order of this Court.IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that all motion to dismiss practice in these actions is stayed pending a ruling by the MDL Panel on the motion to transfer. If the MDL Panel denies the motion, the Court will schedule a conference with the remaining defendants to establish a schedule for the remainder of pretrial proceedings in these actions. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 2/7/2014) (gr) (Entered: 02/07/2014)

Original Docket Text: SCHEDULING ORDER:Pursuant to the conference held on March 11, 2014, the following schedule shall govern the further conduct of pretrial proceedings in these cases:1.Following the Opinion of January 22, 2014 granting in part the motion to dismiss filed by defendants Morgan Stanley et al. in 13 Civ. 6705, defendant Wachovia Capital Markets, n/k/a Wells Fargo Securities, filed a motion to dismiss in 13 Civ. 6719 on February 5. In an Order of February 7, the motion was stayed, along with all motion to dismiss practice by the remaining defendants. The stay is now lifted. If any of the remaining defendants wishes to file a motion to dismiss in the listed actions, the following schedule shall apply: Motion served by March 25, 2014 (if not already done so). Opposition served by April 15, 2014. Reply served by April 25, 2014. (PLEASE SEE SCHEDULING ORDER FOR THE REST OF THE SCHEDULE AND JUDGE COTE'S PROCEDURES). (Signed by Judge Denise L. Original Docket Text: ORDER...[T]that the obligation to produce transcripts, affidavits and affirmations, as described in § 10(d) of the April 9, 2014 Master Discovery Protocol, is not limited to the parties current and former employees, and does include the obligation to produce such materials from non-parties. The defendants shall provide NCUA with lists of third-party transcripts, and the parties shall confer in good faith to identify those transcripts that may be of assistance to the parties in this litigation. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the defendants shall complete production of the third-party transcripts under § 10(d) of the April 9, 2014 Master Discovery Protocol by June 13, 2014. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the defendants request to remove the provision in § 7(c) of the April 9, 2014 Master Discovery Protocol that previously served interrogatories shall count against the totals set forth in § 7(a) is denied. The parties are reminded that any request to deviate from the Master Discovery Protocol must be supported by a showing of good cause. See Master Discovery Protocol § 1. Signed by Judge Denise L. Original Docket Text: ORDER....that the parties, except any party as to whom a stay has been entered, shall jointly submit a single status report regarding the Loan File Protocol. The report may exceed two pages. It shall be accompanied by a chart indicating among other things the number of sample loans in each action, the number of loan files produced to NCUA for that sample, and the percentage produced. Where the percentage is less than 100%, the chart should indicate in whose custody it is believed that the missing loan files reside. To the extent a defendant is believed to be the custodian of a missing loan file, the defendant, except any defendant as to whom a stay has been entered, shall separately explain its failure to produce the loan file by June 27, 2014, or the date of the last status report to the Court. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the agreements of NCUA, Goldman Sachs, and RBS to extend the defendants time to respond to the NCUA requests for stipulations, as reflected in the NCUA letter of July 11, are approved nunc pro tunc. In the future, the parties may on consent extend the time to so stipulate with the understanding that any disagreements regarding the twenty-one day period for stipulation must be promptly brought to the Courts attention. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote (S.D.N.Y.), Judge George H. Wu (C.D. Cal.), Judge John W. Lungstrum (D. Kan.), Magistrate Judge James P. OHara (D. Kan.) on 7/14/2014) (gr) (Entered: 07/14/2014)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: On October 1, 2014, at 11:00 a.m. (Central), with Judge Lungstrum chairing, the four undersigned judges will conduct a telephone status conference with the parties lead counsel. Beyond discovery governed by the Master Discovery Protocol in these coordinated cases, the purpose of this conference is to discuss case management issues that might be presented by the interrogatory answers of plaintiff National Credit Union Administration, as recently challenged in the RBS defendants motion in limine (e.g., ECF doc. 403 in D. Kan. Case No. 11-2340, denied by Judge Lungstrum on September 22, 2014) and as delineated in RBS's letter/filing in response to Judge Wu's Order Taking Motion in Limine Off-Calendar (see Docket Nos. 333 & 335 in C.D.Ca. Case No. 11-5887). By September 30, 2014, at 12:00 p.m. (Central), lead counsel for NCUA shall file a two-page response in all of the above-captioned cases, addressing the merits of the RBS defendants stated concerns that NCUA is improperly attempting to broaden its claims without benefit of a formal motion to amend the pleadings. Mindful that the court will only be able to allow a total of 12 call-in lines for this conference call, all lead counsel who intend to participate shall send a confirmatory e-mail addressed to Judge OHaras chambers (ksd_ohara_chambers@ksd.uscourts.gov), by September 30, 2014, at 12:00 p.m. (Central). Counsel may join the conference call by dialing (913) 735-2289. (Signed by Judge Denise Cote on 9/26/14) (SR) (Entered: 09/26/2014)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: On April 9, 2014 Master Discovery Protocol ("MDP") has been entered in these coordinated actions. Section 12(a) of the MDP required parties to make a significant document production by June 6 and to "substantially complete" their document production by October 31, 2014. The MDP is hereby amended to add the following deadlines: 1. By October 31, 2014, each party shall certify that it has substantially completed its document production. 2. Without limiting the obligations imposed by Fed.R.Civ.P. 26(e), all parties must fully supplement their Fed.R.Civ.P 26 disclosures and all discovery responses served to date by November 7, 2014. 3. In each action, the deadline by which any party may move to amend its pleadings or join additional parties is November 14, 2014. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote (S.D.N.Y.), Judge George H. Wu (C.D. Cal.), Judge John W. Lungstrum (D. Kan.), Magistrate Judge James P. OHara (D. Kan.) on 10/3/2014) (gr) (Entered: 10/03/2014)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: In a letter of January 21, 2015, NCUA presents four requests for further discovery in these coordinated actions from Credit Suisse. Credit Suisse opposes each request in a submission of January 26.....Having reviewed these requests, it is herebyORDERED that the parties shall meet and confer regarding NCUAs request for a more complete production of quality control reviews and audits of the Credit Suisse due diligence providers. Credit Suisse has represented that there is no centralized repository for such documents. During the meet and confer process, Credit Suisse shall identify any custodians or repositories of which it is aware that are likely to possess a more comprehensive set of such documents. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the parties shall meet and confer regarding any burden associated with locating and producing the work papers and drafts associated with the final audit reports for which Credit Suisse has agreed to search. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, Credit Suisse having identified more than 125 employees as directly involved in the Securitizations, Credit Suisse shall provide to NCUA more detail about the roles each of these employees performed and their connection to the specific Securitizations at issue in these cases. The parties shall then confer regarding the production by Credit Suisse of the performance reviews for a subset of the identified employees.IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, Credit Suisse having refused to identify the transaction managers for the Securitizations, Credit Suisse shall now add Helen Cheung and Kevin Steele as custodians. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that NCUAs request to add Timothy Callahan, Todd Terakedis and Paul Heckman as custodians is denied. Credit Suisse represents that the supervisor for the unit that conducted due diligence on the loans included in the Securitizations, which is the unit in which Callahan and Terakedis worked, is already a custodian. Credit Suisse also represents that the head of the unit in which Heckman worked and a colleague who performed a similar function as an account executive are already custodians. (Signed by Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote (S.D.N.Y.), Judge George H. Wu (C.D. Cal.), Judge John W. Lungstrum (D. Kan.), Magistrate Judge James P. OHara (D. Kan.) on 1/28/2015) (gr) (Entered: 01/28/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER...that, if a motion pertaining to these coordinated actions is made in a court other than our three Courts (such as the motion discussed in NCUAs May 19 letter), the parties implicated by that motion shall convey to the judicial officer to whom the motion is assigned that our Courts stand ready and willing to accept transfer of the motion. The parties shall also convey that a transfer of the motion can be effected by transferring the motion to the Hon. Denise Cote in the Southern District of New York, whereafter it shall be ruled upon following consultation among Judge Cote, Judges Lungstrum and/or OHara, and Judge Wu. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that promptly after any such transfer the party seeking the discovery shall file in each district in this coordinated litigation copies of the motion papers related to the dispute. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the parties shall also convey to the judicial officer to whom such a motion is addressed that, pursuant to the Master Discovery Protocol and a May 13, 2015 Order entered in these coordinated actions, our Courts have mechanisms in place for resolving disputes that arise both in advance of and during a deposition. Original Docket Text: ORDER...that the transfer of the Whittemore motion is accepted as one made pursuant to § 2 of the MDP. To the extent it has not already done so, NCUA shall promptly file its own and all of Whittemores submissions to date in each of our three districts. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that NCUAs opposition is due June 11 at noon (EDT). IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that any reply by Whittemore is due June 15 at noon (EDT). In the normal course, discovery disputes between the parties in these Coordinated Actions have been resolved on the basis of one submission by the party raising the dispute and one responsive submission from the adverse party (or parties); generally, replies by the party raising the dispute have not been required or accepted. Because Whittemores motion is a formal motion made by a nonparty, however, he is given the opportunity to submit a reply. As Whittemores counsel entered a June 10 notice of appearance on ECF in the lead action in the Southern District of New York, No. 13cv6705 (DLC), Dkt. No. 320, Whittemores counsel shall file any reply on that docket. Judge Cote will promptly forward any submission to the other Judges. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote (S.D.N.Y.), Judge George H. Original Docket Text: ORDER....On July 9, RBS applied to our Courts to take the Barclays deposition on August 5, outside the discovery cutoff date. Early on July 11, RBS advised NCUA and our Courts that it was withdrawing its request to take the deposition in August, and that RBS and Barclays had agreed on a date for the deposition to occur before July 17. Shortly thereafter, RBS served a deposition notice identifying the date for the deposition as July 14. NCUA contends that it cannot reasonably prepare for the deposition in one business day. Considering issues of diligence, reasonable notice, and convenience to a third-party witness, it is hereby ORDERED that the NCUA request to cancel the Barclays Rule 30(b)(6) deposition scheduled for July 14 is denied. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote (S.D.N.Y.), Judge George H. Wu (C.D. Cal.), Judge John W. Lungstrum (D. Kan.), Magistrate Judge James P. OHara (D. Kan.)on 7/13/2015) (gr) (Entered: 07/13/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: The parties to these actions, to the extent they have not already done so, shall by September 25 schedule mediation or settlement sessions to take place no later than October 30. The sessions shall be attended by a principal with full settlement authority. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the parties shall file a report detailing their compliance with the above by September 25. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the trials in these matters will proceed in two tranches. Trials for cases in the first tranche will begin on June 20, 2016 and trials for cases in the second tranche will begin on September 12, 2016. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the cases in the first tranche of trials shall be as follows: NCUA v. Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., et al., No. 13cv6705; NCUA v. Wachovia Capital Markets LLC, No. 13cv6719; NCUA v. Goldman, Sachs & Co., No. 13cv6721; NCUA v. UBS Securities, LLC, No. 13cv6731. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the cases in the second tranche of trials shall be as follows: NCUA v. Barclays Capital, Inc., No. 13cv6727; NCUA v. Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC, et al., No. 13cv6736. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, to the extent cases in the first tranche are resolved before trial, cases in the second tranche may be shifted to the first tranche. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the composition of the first tranche shall be finalized on March 18, 2016. (Signed by Judge Denise Cote on 9/18/15) (tg) (Entered: 09/18/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: On February 1, 2016, the Court issued an order permitting the parties in the above-captioned actions to file their summary judgment papers under seal, and allowing the parties to agree on redactions to those documents by February 26. On February 5, NCUA, UBS, and Credit Suisse filed motions for summary judgment and moving papers in support of their respective motions. The moving papers for some of the motions contained voluminous documents to be filed under seal. By order dated February 8, the Court permitted NCUA to file documents under seal bearing signatures made by an agent, and to file one set of voluminous documents in both the UBS and Credit Suisse cases. Accordingly, it is hereby ORDERED that the parties shall file all future sealed documents bearing the original signature of an attorney listed on ECF, and shall not submit documents signed by designation or by an agent. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that voluminous sealed documents relevant to both the UBS and the Credit Suisse case may be filed in only one case, and the Clerk of Court shall file a notification on ECF for the other case indicating that sealed documents have been filed under a different docket number. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 2/18/2016) (gr) (Entered: 02/18/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER....that the categories of redactions proposed by Credit Suisse, namely (a) nonparty borrower information (such as names, loan numbers, social security numbers, addresses, credit scores, and similar information); (b) personal information; (c) transcripts of testimony from government regulatory investigations; and (d) proprietary or trade secret information, are approved (the Approved Categories). IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the revised redactions proposed by NCUA concerning the BlackRock information are approved. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, with respect to redactions falling outside the Approved Categories, including those made because of a protective order with a third party, the parties shall contact the relevant third parties to determine if any basis exists to continue the redactions of those materials. By March 16, the parties shall make a submission identifying any redactions falling outside the Approved Categories that third parties contend should remain in place. In the submission, the parties shall identify for each redaction: (1) the third party making the request, (2) the document, (3) the page number, (4) the paragraph (if applicable), (5) the sentence (if applicable), and (6) the justification for the proposed redaction. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 3/9/2016) (gr) (Entered: 03/09/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: On March 16, 2016, NCUA provided redaction requests by Barclays for summary judgment papers filed in the above-captioned action on February 5. The Barclays requests relate to its work for NCUA on certain guaranteed notes, the NGN Program. The requested redactions affect (1) NCUAs Memorandum in support of its motion for summary judgment regarding damages, (2) a Rule 56.1 Statement, and (3) various exhibits to multiple summary judgment motions. Having reviewed Barclays requests, it is hereby ORDERED that the redaction requests for the Rule 56.1 Statement and the exhibits are approved. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the requested redactions to the Memorandum are denied with the following exceptions. NCUA may redact only the specific numerical figures reflecting Barclays projections on pages 5, 8, 9, 10, 12, 28, and 31. For example, NCUA may redact the two numbers in the sentence on page 9 that begins with the phrase Barclays projected that... and the number in the following sentence that begins with the phrase [i]n other words.... IT IS FURTHER ORDERED the parties shall by April 5, file revised versions of their summary judgment documents consistent with this order, the Courts March 9 order, and the Courts March 17 endorsed letter. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 3/22/2016) (gr) (Entered: 03/22/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: On March 24, 2016, NCUA filed a notice that it has accepted a Rule 68 offer of judgment from Credit Suisse in the amount of $29,014,643, plus prejudgment interest in an amount to be determined by the Court. The notice reports that the parties will attempt to reach an agreement regarding the amount of costs and attorneys fees to be paid by Credit Suisse. Accordingly, it is hereby ORDERED that by May 12, the parties shall submit a status update on the progress of their negotiations concerning attorneys fees and costs. In the event the parties have not reached an agreement, their submission shall also propose a briefing schedule on the issue of attorneys fees and costs. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 3/24/2016) (gr) (Entered: 03/24/2016)

Original Docket Text: OPINION AND ORDER #106374.....The Defendants February 5, 2016 Motion for Partial Summary Judgment on the Proper Calculation of Prejudgment Interest is granted insofar as (1) prejudgment interest shall be calculated based on the declining principal balance for each Certificate and (2) prejudgment interest under the TSA and ISL shall be calculated using the coupon rate applicable for each Certificate. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 3/24/2016) (gr) Modified on 4/8/2016 (ca). (Entered: 03/24/2016)
Removed unnecessary POS & vocab: opinion order motion partial summary judgment proper calculation prejudgment interest grant insofar prejudgment interest calculate base decline principal balance certificate prejudgment interest calculate use coupon rate applicable certificate

Original Docket Text: ORDER....In an Opinion and Order dated March 24, the Court held that (1) prejudgment interest shall be calculated based on the declining principal balance for each Certificate and (2) prejudgment interest under the TSA and ISL shall be calculated using the coupon rate applicable for each Certificate. Accordingly, it is hereby ORDERED that if the parties dispute the amount of prejudgment interest owed using the methodology and rate set forth in the Courts March 24 Opinion and Order, they shall address the issue in their submissions to the Court concerning attorneys fees and costs, which is due on April 15 for the UBS matter and on May 12 for the Credit Suisse matter. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 3/25/2016) (gr) (Entered: 03/25/2016)
