Original Docket Text: JUDGMENT: Whereas Defendants Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC and Credit Suisse First Boston Mortgage Securities Corp. (collectively "Defendants") having offered to allow judgment to be taken against it by Plaintiff National Credit Union Administration Board ("NCUA") in the total amount for damages of $50,312,048, (inclusive of pre-judgment interest); and that the parties shall continue to meet and confer regarding the amount of attorneys' fees and costs to be paid by Credit Suisse and will submit a status update by May 12, 2016, it is, ORDERED, ADJUDGED, AND DECREED, that NCUA is entitled to total damages (inclusive of pre-judgment interest) of $50,312,048 as of April 22, 2016, and Credit Suisse shall make payment of $50,312,048 to NCUA as of that date; and the parties shall continue to meet and confer regarding the amount of attorneys' fees and costs to be paid by Credit Suisse and will submit a status update by May 12, 2016. (Signed by Judge Denise L. Cote on 4/22/2016) (Attachments: # 1 Right to Appeal, # 2 Right to Appeal)(kko) (Entered: 04/22/2016)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION AND ORDER OF DISMISSAL WITH PREJUDICE AS TO DEFENDANT ROSENWACH TANK COMPANY, INC. ONLY. The parties execute this stipulation of dismissal with prejudice with the understanding that litigation and discovery will continue against the other parties in this action and that Aegis will continue to conduct litigation and discovery in a good faith effort to examine potential claims which may exist against Rosenwach Tank Co., Inc. The running of any statute of limitations, laches, repose, notice requirements, scheduling orders, or other limitations period shall be suspended and tolled, indefinitely, and Aegis will have the right to recommence this action against Rosenwach Tank, Co., Inc. if the information and/or representations contained in the affidavit of Andrew Rosenwach is materially inaccurate. Accrual of interest on any amount ultimately to be awarded to Aegis/ConEd from the Rosenwach Tank Co., Inc. with respect to the claims, if any, shall not be suspended during the effective term of this stipulation in the event an action is recommenced against Rosenwach Tank Co., Inc. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 7/1/05) (yv, ) (Entered: 07/12/2005)

Original Docket Text: CASE MANAGEMENT ORDER... All attorneys who have been admitted to this Court, either for all purposes or pro hac vice for purposes of this case who are not yet registered to file documents electronically, shall complete and file a CM/ECF attorney registration form by November 1, 2006. Forms can be found on the Court's website at www.nysd.uscourts.gov. As of October 17, 2006 all documents filed in the Miscellaneous case and the underlying civil cases shall be filed electronically on the Court's ECF system via the Internet at ecf.nysd.uscourts.gov. All correspondences are to be submitted in either Word or WordPerfect format to WTC_letters@nysd.uscourts.gov. The subject heading of the email must include the case number of the action or actions that the email pertains to. No correspondences are to be sent to Chambers through regular mail. No correspondences should be in the form of a motion. Amended complaints and supplemental pleading shall provide a list of the additional parties and indicate the action to which they are being added... (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 10/17/2006) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH,1:02-cv-02987-AKH,1:02-cv-07188-AKH,1:02-cv-07198-AKH,1:02-cv-10052-AKH, 1:03-cv-00131-AKH,1:03-cv-06925-AKH,1:04-cv-04577-AKH,1:04-cv-05020-AKH,1:04-cv-05021-AKH, 1:04-cv-05022-AKH,1:04-cv-05023-AKH,1:04-cv-05024-AKH,1:04-cv-05025-AKH,1:04-cv-06848-AKH, 1:04-cv-07136-AKH,1:04-cv-07199-AKH,1:04-cv-07225-AKH,1:04-cv-07231-AKH,1:04-cv-07234-AKH, 1:04-cv-07238-AKH,1:04-cv-07240-AKH,1:04-cv-07241-AKH,1:04-cv-07244-AKH,1:04-cv-07246-AKH, 1:04-cv-07248-AKH,1:04-cv-07272-AKH,1:04-cv-07294-AKH,1:04-cv-07299-AKH,1:04-cv-07318-AKH(mj, ) Modified on 12/5/2006 (mj, ). Original Docket Text: ORDER DENYING MOTION FOR SANCTIONS AND REGULATING PROCEEDINGS. Plaintiff Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. ("Con Edison") has moved for summary judgment on Counts Three and Four of its Second Amended Complaint. As the motion is now fully briefed, the parties shall appear before me for oral argument on February 23, 2009, at 4:00 p.m. The status conference in the above-captioned cases currently scheduled for February 6, 2009 is hereby adjourned to occur in conjunction with the oral argument on February 23, 2009. In addition, Con Edison moves to sanction the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey ("Port Authority") for relying, in its opposition papers, on various assertions in a report by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), and to strike these assertions or Port Authority's opposition papers in full. Alternatively, Con Edison asks for leave to file an additional submission to respond to Port Authority's use of the NIST Report. The motion to strike and for sanctions is denied, in both of its parts. A case for sanctions has not been made. If the Court finds the assertions from the NIST Report worthy of consideration, Con Edison may ask for an opportunity to comment. In its papers, Port Authority comments that Con Edison filed its motion for partial summary judgment before discovery was completed. I wish to know what additional discovery is expected or planned that the parties reasonably anticipate will elicit admissible evidence to clarify their contemporaneous understandings of the meaning of the relevant clauses of the lease agreement. Both parties' submissions on this question will be due on February 13, 2009, at 12:00 p.m. The Clerk shall mark the motion to strike and for sanctions (Doc. #152) as terminated. ( Oral Argument set for 2/23/2009 at 04:00 PM before Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein.), Motions terminated: (152 in 1:02-cv-07188-AKH) MOTION to Strike Document No. [146, 147, 148]. Original Docket Text: SCHEDULING ORDER. Asserting standing as claimants to a limited fund, the World Trade Center Properties Plaintiffs moved on February 12, 2009 for summary judgment dismissing all subrogation claims against the Aviation Defendants in the 21 MC 101 docket. The Aviation Defendants moved for the same relief on March 13, 2009. On March 30, 2009, the defendants in 04 Civ. 7272, a case relating to 7 World Trade Center and administered in the 21 MC 101 docket, moved for partial summary judgment dismissing the subrogation claims asserted against them in that action. Each motion presents the same question regarding the New York law of subrogation rights. The parties shall appear before me for oral argument on the motions on June 16, 2009, at 4:00 p.m. The Aviation Defendants will present the principal argument on behalf of the movants. The other movants will be heard only to the extent that they assert separate grounds for the relief sought. Oral Argument set for 6/16/2009 at 04:00 PM before Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 5/20/09) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH, 1:04-cv-07272-AKH(rjm) (Entered: 05/21/2009)

Original Docket Text: SCHEDULING ORDER. Two hearings have been scheduled for July 15, 2009: a status conference in the 7 World Trade Center litigation, and an oral argument on the three motions for judgment dismissing the claims of all subrogated insurers in the 21 MC 101 docket and in 04 Civ. 7272. By letter dated June 29, 2009, the parties to the 7 World Trade Center actions seek to extend the fact discovery deadline from June 30, 2009 to August 31, 2009. By July 22, 2009, the parties shall submit letters (1) showing cause for any additional depositions that either party wishes to take; and (2) stating if such additional discovery would present new information relevant to the sub judice issues in 02 Civ. 7188, as described in my order of May 21, 2009. The status conference scheduled for July 15, 2009 is hereby cancelled. The conference will be rescheduled when, in light of the parties' submissions, I rule as to whether to allow additional discovery. The oral argument on the three motions concerning subrogation rights will occur as scheduled on July 15, 2009, at 2:30 p.m. Fact Discovery due by 8/31/2009. Oral Argument set for 7/15/2009 at 02:30 PM before Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 7/7/09) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH, 1:02-cv-07188-AKH, 1:04-cv-07272-AKH(rjm) (Entered: 07/07/2009)

Original Docket Text: ORDER. By letter dated July 31, 2009, the parties propose a schedule for depositions of fact witnesses, all to be completed by October 30, 2009. I approve this schedule. In addition, I note that Con Edison will receive insurance proceeds in the amount of $37,580,750 pursuant to my Opinion and Order of July 27, 2009, and that Con Edison has also received insurance proceeds in at least that amount from its subrogated property insurers. Accordingly, I order the parties to address whether Con Edison, having been twice compensated for its loss, may pursue claims against Defendants in this action. The parties shall exchange draft responses, and then submit a joint letter by August 14, 2009. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 8/3/09) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH, 1:04-cv-07272-AKH(rjm) (Entered: 08/04/2009)

Original Docket Text: OPINION AND ORDER DENYING MOTIONS TO DISMISS ALL CLAIMS OF SUBROGATED INSURERS: # 97893 For the reasons discussed in this opinion, I hold that § 4545 did not affect insurers' subrogation rights. In terms of the motions before me, although § 4545 may bar the WTCP Plaintiffs and Con Edison from recovering damages for which they have been compensated by their insurers, it does not bar their insurers, who have been "compelled by contract to pay the loss caused by the negligence of another," Winkelmann, 85 N.Y.2d at 581, from asserting subrogation rights against the alleged tortfeasors. The Clerk shall mark the motions (Docs. #724 & #756 in 21 MC 101, and #359 in 04 Civ. 7272) as terminated. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 8/13/2009) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH, 1:04-cv-07272-AKH(rw) Modified on 8/14/2009 (eef). (Entered: 08/13/2009)

Original Docket Text: ORDER APPROVING ESCROW ACCOUNT AS A QUALIFIED SETTLEMENT FUND. IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT: 1. The Fund shall be established pursuant to and consistent with the terms of this Order; 2. The Fund shall be named the "911 Lit PD Plaintiffs Stt Fd"; 3. The Fund shall be established as a Qualified Settlement Fund within the meaning of Internal Revenue Code § 468B and Treasury Regulation §1.468B-l; 4. The Garretson Firm Resolution Group, Inc. is appointed as Fund Administrator; 5. The Fund Administrator shall act in accordance with the terms, conditions and restrictions as the Settling Parties shall mutually agree; 6. The Fund Administrator, in conjunction with the Escrow Agent, shall take action to ensure that a proper account is opened; 7. The Fund Administrator is authorized to coordinate and oversee all necessary distributions from the Fund, including the payment of taxes, attorney's fees and litigation expenses to counsel consistent with their fee contracts, and is authorized to effect any qualified assignments that relate to the payment of attorney's fees, subject to the terms and conditions of the Settling Parties' agreement(s); 8. The Fund Administrator, in consultation with the Settling Parties, shall be responsible for coordinating and overseeing the Escrow Agent with respect to final distributions from the Fund, after payment of fees, expenses and taxes, to recipients when the conditions mutually agreed by the Settling Parties are satisfied and consistent with the terms and conditions of the Settling Parties' agreement(s); 9. The Fund Administrator is authorized, upon final completion of all Fund activities and final distribution of all monies to be paid into the Fund, to take appropriate steps to wind-down the Fund and thereafter the Fund Administrator is discharged from any further responsibility with respect to the Fund. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 1/29/10) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH et al.(rjm) (Entered: 01/29/2010)

Original Docket Text: ENDORSED LETTER addressed to Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein from Franklin M. Sachs dated 11/19/2010 re: We represent the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and the Aegis plaintiffs (collectively "Con Edison") in the above-referenced matter. We are writing in response to the letter dated November 12, 2010, submitted by Kathleen L. Pringle, Esq. on behalf of the Silverstein entities. In her letter, Ms. Pringle brings to the courts attention a new case, Henry-Lee v. City of New York. 2010 WL 3855238 (S.D.N.Y. September 30, 2010) and discusses Your Honor's holding in the matter In re September 11 litigation, Consolidated Edison Co. v. The Port Authority, 2010 WL 3432264 (S.D.N.Y. September 1, 2010). We will discuss each case in turn. Finally, in preparing for oral argument with respect to Citigroup's Motion for Summary Judgment we found a significant case that had previously escaped our attention, Paul Brothers v New York State Electric and Gas Corp., 11 N.Y.3d 251 (2008). With the Court's permission, we will be relying on that case in our oral argument on December 16. ENDORSEMENT: Having received this letter and the letter from 7 World Trade Company on 11/12/10, briefing is now closed. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 11/19/2010) (jmi) (Entered: 11/23/2010)

Original Docket Text: JUDGMENT The Judgment dated September 29, 2011 is vacated and judgment is hereby entered as follows: That, for the reasons stated in the Court's Opinion and Order dated September 23, 2011, summary judgment is granted to 7WTCo., Silverstein Properties, Inc., and Silverstein Developement Corp. (collectively the "7WTCc. Defendants"), and to citigroup Inc., Citigroup Global Markets Holdings, Inc., Salomon Smith Barney Holdings Inc. and Salomon Inc. (collectively the "Citigroup Defendants"), dismissing all remaining claims by plaintiffs against them. As the decision resolves the last claims in Civil Action No. 04 Civ. 7272, the Second Amended Complaint is dismissed, accordingly, judgment is entered for Defendants on all claims by Plaintiffs, the remaining Cross Claims are dismissed without prejudice, and the case is closed. (Signed by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein on 11/3/11) (Attachments: # 1 Notice of Right to Appeal)Filed In Associated Cases: 1:21-mc-00101-AKH, 1:04-cv-07272-AKH(dt) (Entered: 11/04/2011)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: By letter briefs, the parties dispute whether plaintiff is entitled to a jury trial as requested. For the reasons set forth below, the court hereby grants plaintiff's request for a jury trial and denies defendants' request for a bench trial. The Court previously scheduled this trial to begin on September 24, 2007 on the assumption that it would be a bench trial. In light of the determination that the case will be tried by jury, however, the window of time previously alloted for this trial is no longer edequate. The parties are directed to jointly telephone Chambers by no later than September 5, 2007 to schedule a new trial date. So Ordered. (Signed by Judge Jed S. Rakoff on 8/30/07) (js) (Entered: 08/31/2007)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: Within five days of this Order, AIG shall produce to AXA copies of those portions of the transcript of the hearing in the DP Mann arbitration containing the testimony of any AIG or broker witness. AIG shall produce together with each transcript copies of any exhibit referred to in the transcript. All transcripts produced by AIG relating to the DP Mann arbitration may be used by AXA at trial solely for impeachment purposes. AXA shall maintain all transcripts produced pursuant to this Order as confidential subject to the Confidentiality Order filed on 6/19/2006. (Signed by Judge Jed S. Rakoff on 10/5/2007) (jar) (Entered: 10/09/2007)

STANDING ORDER IN RE PILOT PROJECT REGARDING CASE MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES FOR COMPLEX CIVIL CASES IN THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK (See M-10-468 Order filed November 1, 2011). This case is hereby designated for inclusion in the Pilot Project Regarding Case Management Techniques for Complex Civil Cases in the Southern District of New York (the Pilot Project), unless the judge to whom this case is assigned determines otherwise. This case is designated for inclusion in the Pilot Project because it is a class action, an MDL action, or is in one of the following Nature of Suit categories: 160, 245, 315, 355, 365, 385, 410, 830, 840, 850, 893, or 950. The presiding judge in a case that does not otherwise qualify for inclusion in the Pilot Project may nevertheless designate the case for inclusion in the Pilot Project by issuing an order directing that the case be included in the Pilot Project. The description of the Pilot Project, including procedures to be followed, is attached to this Order. (Signed by Judge Loretta A. Preska on 10/31/2011) (mro) (Entered: 08/13/2012)

Original Docket Text: Letter addressed to Judge Denise L. Cote from Roger R. Crane, Jr. dated 2/1/2013 re: Plaintiff's counsel writes we represent plaintiff Shareholder Representative Services LLC (the "Stockholders' Representative") in connection with the above-referenced action. As you requested, we are responding to your inquiry as to whether we intended to withdraw the present action and commence a new action. Please be advised that we have decided not to do so and instead are sending today, as you suggested, to defense counsel our proposed second amended complaint. You also mentioned that you thought a dismissal of the complaint on the grounds of lack of standing would be a dismissal with prejudice. We have looked into the issue and believe the law is clear that the dismissal would be without prejudice. See Alliance for Envtl. Renewal, Inc. v. Pyramid Crossgates Co., 436 F.3d 82, 89, n. 6 (2d Cir. 2006); In re Vivendi Universal, S.A. Sees. Litig., 605 F.Supp.2d 570, 584 (S.D.N.Y. 2009). Needless to say, we will brief this issue more fully if a motion to dismiss is filed based on the ground of lack of standing.. Document filed by Shareholder Representative Services LLC.(ago) (Entered: 02/04/2013)

ORDER OF SERVICE: By order dated August 9, 2016, the Court granted Plaintiff's request to proceed without prepayment of fees, that is, informa pauperis. To allow Plaintiff to effect service on Defendants through the U.S. Marshals Service, the Clerk of Court is instructed to fill out a U.S. Marshals Service Process Receipt and Return form ("USM-285 form") for each of these defendants. The service address for Defendants Machael Spencer-Edwards and Judith Brown is 982 Hegeman Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11208. The service address for Defendant Joyce Stallings-Harte is 557 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11207. The service address for Defendants Corinne Rello-Anselmi, Carme Farina, and the New York City Department of Education is 100 Church Street, New York, New York 10007. The Clerk of Court is further instructed to issue a summons and deliver to the Marshals Service all of the paperwork necessary for the Marshals Service to effect service upon these defendants. It is Plaintiff's responsibility to ensure that service is made within 90 days of the date the summons is issued and, if necessary, to request an extension of time for service. See Meilleur v. Strong, 682 F.3d 56, 63 (2d Cir. 2012). Plaintiff also must notify the Court in writing if her address changes, and the Court may dismiss the action if she fails to do so. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge Analisa Torres on 8/17/2016) (kl) (Entered: 08/17/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: Accordingly, Plaintiff's request for leave to amend is DENIED without prejudice to a renewed motion accompanied by either (1) a proposed amended complaint or (2) a detailed explanation of the proposed amendments sufficient to show why these amendments would not be futile. Plaintiff's alternative request for a third extension of time to file her opposition to Defendants' motion to dismiss is GRANTED in part. By April 19, 2017, Plaintiff shall file her opposition, and by May 3, 2017, Defendants shall reply. No further extension shall be granted. If Plaintiff does not oppose Defendants' motion by this date, the motion will be considered fully submitted. (As further sets forth in this Order.) Original Docket Text: ORDER granting 43 Letter Motion for Extension of Time. Defendants have indicated that rather than renew their motion to dismiss as against plaintiff's proposed amended complaint (or modify it as a result of the proposed amended complaint), they wish instead to oppose plaintiff's motion to amend her complaint. They do not propose any time frame by which to file their opposition. Accordingly, the Court will give the Defendants until May 12 to file any opposition to the motion. Defendants should be mindful that, in this Circuit, a pro se complaint should not be dismissed without the Court granting leave to amend at least once when a liberal reading of the complaint gives any indication that a valid claim might be stated. Dolan v. Connolly, 794 F.3d 290, 295 (2d Cir. 2015) (internal quotations and alterations omitted). Moreover, Rule 15(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure mandates that leave to amend should be freely give[n]... when justice so requires. [T]his mandate is to be heeded. Foman v. Davis, 371 U.S. 178, 182 (1962). Here, this would be Plaintiff's first amendment of her pleading. Accordingly, Defendants should make clear in their opposition why they are taking the position that the motion to amend should not be granted, rather than agreeing to the filing of an amended complaint without prejudice to a renewed motion to dismiss if Defendants believe the amended complaint is deficient (or alternatively filing an answer to the amended complaint). Defendants are directed to provide a copy of this text-only order to the pro se Plaintiff forthwith. (HEREBY ORDERED by Magistrate Judge James L. Cott)(Text Only Order) Copies of Notice of Electronic Filing To Be Mailed By Clerks Office. (Cott, James) (Entered: 05/04/2017)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: The Court held a conference today at which the parties agreed that pro se plaintiff's deposition shall take place on February 27, 2018 at 100 Church St., New York, New York 10007. Defendants shall provide plaintiff with additional information regarding the deposition. As the Court informed plaintiff at the conference, failure to attend the deposition could result in the dismissal of the complaint for failure to prosecute. The Court also made the following amendments to the November 2, 2017 scheduling order (Dkt. No. 70): 1. All discovery shall be completed by March 9, 2018. 2. Following the close of discovery, defendants shall file their anticipated motion for summary judgment by April 13, 2018. Plaintiff shall file her response opposing the motion by May 14. Defendants shall file their reply, if any, by May 29. Any requests for a modification to this schedule should be directed to Judge Torres. If defendants decide not to file a summary judgment motion, they should contact Judge Torres by letter no later than April 13 to so advise her and to request a conference with her. Defendants' counsel is directed to confirm with plaintiff that she has received a copy of this order. Motions due by 4/13/2018. Responses due by 5/14/2018 Replies due by 5/29/2018. Deposition due by 4/27/2018. Discovery due by 3/9/2018. (Signed by Magistrate Judge James L. Cott on 1/29/2018) Copies Mailed and E-Mailed By Chambers. (kgo) (Entered: 01/29/2018)

Original Docket Text: OPINION AND ORDER #86305, I find that AW unlawfully converted Phansalkar's 385,902 MCEL Shares. I further find that Phansalkar's failure to disclose certain directors' compensation and Board seat opportunities breached his duty of loyalty and good faith to AW. However, I have determined that these isolated misdeeds did not constitute a scheme of defraud AW or so taint his employment relationship as to warrant forfeiture of his MCEL Shares. Accordingly, (1) AW's claim that Phansalkar's acts of disloyalty requir him to forfeit his MCEL Shares is Denied. (2) it is Ordered that Phansalkar recover: (a) judgment in his favor against AW in the amount of $4,417,655.40; (b) interest on $2,945,700.00, at the rate of nine percent (9%) per annum from 5/4/01 to the date of judgment; and (c) interest on $1,471,995.40, at the rate of nine percent (9%) per annum from 5/21/01 to the date of judgment; to be calculated by the Clerk of the Court, as allowed by law. (3) It is further Ordered that AW recover judgment in its favor against Phansalkar for an amount, to be determined at a later date, representing the compensation Phansalkar earned on the specific transactions where he was disloyal . ( signed by Judge Shira A. Scheindlin ); Copies mailed. (Orig. doc. sent to the Judgment Clerk) (ae) (Entered: 11/30/2001)

Original Docket Text: JUDGMENT #01,2189: that for the reasons stated in the Court's Opinion and Order dtd 11/29/01, judgment is hereby entered: (1) denying that Phansalkar's acts of disloyalty require him to forfeit his MCEL Share; (2) that Phansalkar recover judgment in his favor against AW in the amount of $4,417,655.40, with interest on $2,945,700 of that amount, at 9% per annum from 5/4/01 to date of judgment, amounting to $155,435.90, and interest on $1,471,955.40 of the total amount, at 9% from 5/21/01 to date of judgment, amounting to $71,500.64, and that AW recover in its favor against Phansalkar for an amount to be determined at a later date, representing the compensation Phansalkar earned on the specific transactions where he was disloyal. Original Docket Text: JUDGMENT #01,2189; For the reasons stated in the Court's Opinion (86305) and Order dated November 29, 2001 and Opinion (87102) and Order dated June 26, 2002, AW's claim that Phansalkar's acts of disloyalty require him to forfeit his MCEL Shares is denied; Phansalkar shall recover judgment in his favor against AW in the amount of $4,417,655.40; interest on $2,945,700 of the amount at the rate of 9% per annum May 4, 2001 to date of Judgment of $155,435.90; interest on $1,471,955.40 of the amount at the rate of 9% per annum May 21, 2001 to date of judgment of $71,500.64, for a sum $4,644,591.94; Phansalkar's claim for breach of contract with respect to his Partner Alocatins are denied; However, when AW's interest in Treasure Masters is monetized, Phansalker is entitled to. 375% of the profit net of costs and expenses; AW's claim to Phansalkar's $250,000 received for his work in 1999 is denied; Phansalkar's claim for breach of contract, quantum meruit, unjust enrichment, and promissory estoppel with respect to compensation for 2000 are denied; AW's conversion claim is denied; AW's claims breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty with to Phansalkar's failure to disclose his Zip Options, Osicom Options, the offer of Sync Board seat and Entrada Board are denied; AW shall recover from Phansalkar Judgment in favor on the amount of $3,000 plus interest at the rate of 9% per annum on $1,000 from May 31, 2000 to the date of judgment of $135,12, on $1,000 from June 30, 2000 to the date of judgment of $127.73, and on $1,000 from July 2000 to the date of judgment of $120.08 for a total sum of $3,382.93; Phansalkar must remit his 600 Zip Shares to AW immediately; AW's claim to Phansalkar's Headway shares is denied; Phansalkar's claim to additional Headway shares is denied; Phalsalkar is liable to AW for breach of contract with respect to the $100,000 loan, and as a result, the Court orders that AW recover from Phansalkar judgment in its favor in the amount of $100,000 plus intest at the rate of 8% per annum from April 17, 2000 until August 17, 2000 of $2,673.97, and at a rate of 9% per annum from August 18, 2000 to the date of judgment of $11,564.38, for a total sum of $114,238.35; and Phansalkar's breach of contract claim with respect to his Sorrento Series A. Preferred Shares is denied; accordingly the case is closed; (signed by James Parkison, Clerk of the Court); Mailed copies and notice of right to appeal. Entered On Docket: 07/12/02. (docmt microfilmed on 07/11/02) (djc) Modified on 07/15/2002 (Entered: 07/12/2002)

Original Docket Text: JUDGMENT #01,2189 that for the reasons stated in the Court's Opinion (86305) and Order dated 11/29/01, Opinion (87102) and Order dated 6/26/02, and Order dated 8/9/02. (1) AW's claim that Phansalkar's acts of disloyalty require him to forfeit his MCEL Shares is denied. (2) Phansalkar shall recover: (a) judgment in his favor against AW in the amount of $4,417,655.40; (b) interest on $2,945,700 of the amount at the rate of 9% per annum 5/4/01 to date of judgment of $305,061.53; and (c) interest on $1,471,955.40 of the amount at the rate of 9% per annum from 5/21/01 to date of judgment of $146,267.99, for a total sum of $4,868,984.80. (3) Phansalkar's claims for breach of contract with respect to his Partner Allocations are denied. However, when AW's interest in Treasure Masters is monetized, Phansalker is entitled to .375% of the profit net of costs and expenses; (4) AW's claim to Phansalkar's $250,000 received for his work in 1999 denied; (5) Phansalkar's claim for breach of contract, quantum meruit, unjust enrichment, and promissory estoppel with respect to compensation for 2000 are denied; (6) AW's conversion claim is denied; (7) AW's claims for breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty with respect to Phansalkar's failure to disclose his Zip Options, Osicom Options, the offer of a Sync Board seat and the Entrada Board seat are denied; (8) Phansalkar is liable to AW for breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty with respect to his failure to disclose and remit his Osicom Board Fees and his Zip Shares, and as result, the Court orders that: (a) AW recover from Phansalkar judgment in its favor in the amount of $3,000 plus interest at the rate of 9% per annum on $1,000 from 5/31/00 to date of judgment of $135.12, on $1,000 from 6/30/00 to the date of judgment of $127.73, and on $1,000 from July 2000 to the date of judgment of $120.08 for total sum of $3,382.93; (b) Phansalkar must remit his 600 Zip Shares to AW immediately. (9) AW's claim to Phansalkar's Headway shares is denied; (10) Phansalkar's claim to additional Headway shares is denied; (11) Phansalkar is liable to AW for breach of contract with respect to the $100,000 loan, and as a result, the Court orders that AW recover from Phansalkar judgment in its favor in the amount of $100,000 plus interest at the rate of 8% per annum from 4/17/00 until 8/17/00 of $2,673.97, and at a rate of 9% per annum from 8/18/00 to the date of judgment of $11,564.38, for a total sum of $114,238.35; and (12) Phansalkar's breach of contract claim with respect to his Sorrento Series A. Preferred Shares is denied; accordingly, the case is closed. ( signed by James M. Parkison, Clerk of Court ). Mailed copies and notice of right to appeal. Entered On Docket: 8/23/02. (kw) Modified on 08/27/2002 (Entered: 08/23/2002)

Original Docket Text: NOTICE OF APPEAL by Rohit Phansalkar from [69-1] judgment order, [68-1] order that for the reasons described herein and denials of claims listed herein the Clerk of the Court is Ordered to enter judgment consistent with this opinion and the opinion in Phansakar I, and to close the case, [44-1] order I find that AW unlawfully converted Phansalkar's 385,902 MCEL Shares. I further find that Phansalkar's failure to disclose certain directors' compensation and Board seat opportunities breached his duty of loyalty and good faith to AW. However, I have determined that these isolated misdeeds did not constitute a scheme of defraud AW or so taint his employment relationship as to warrant forfeiture of his MCEL Shares. Accordingly, (1) AW's claim that Phansalkar's acts of disloyalty requir him to forfeit his MCEL Shares is Denied. (2) it is Ordered that Phansalkar recover: (a) judgment in his favor against AW in the amount of $4,417,655.40; (b) interest on $2,945,700.00, at the rate of nine percent (9%) per annum from 5/4/01 to the date of judgment; and (c) interest on $1,471,995.40, at the rate of nine percent (9%) per annum from 5/21/01 to the date of judgment; to be calculated by the Clerk of the Court, as allowed by law. (3) It is further Ordered that AW recover judgment in its favor against Phansalkar for an amount, to be determined at a later date, representing the compensation Phansalkar earned on the specific transactions where he was disloyal . Copies of notice of appeal mailed to Attorney(s) of Record: Jaculin Aaron, Esq. $105.00 Appeal filing fee paid 8/20/02 on receipt # E 0448474. (dt) (Entered: 08/21/2002)

Original Docket Text: ENDORSED LETTER addressed to Magistrate Judge Frank Maas from Stephen L. Ascher dated 3/31/10 re: The parties have agreed to the enclosed Stipulated Confidentiality Agreement and Protective Order ("Order"). Because of thenature of the discovery in this matter, the parties have agreed to certain modifications to Judge Gardephe's Model Stipulated Confidentiality Agreement and Protective Order. These modifications are illustrated in the attached redline comparing the enclosed Order to the court's model order. Please let us know if you have any questions about the parties' enclosed Order, which werespectfully submit for Your Honor's approval. ENDORSEMENT: I am concerned about para. 1 of the proposed order, which, as amended, extends confidentiality to ALL testimony, not just deposition testimony. To my understanding, if confidential information is used during the course of a trial, it loses its prior protection. Either para. 1 needs to be reworded or someone needs to explain to me why my understanding is wrong. (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 3/31/10) (db) (Entered: 04/01/2010)

Original Docket Text: ORDER TO COMPEL DEFENDANTS' PRODUCTION OF DOCUMENTS, that notwithstanding any French bank secrecy or blocking statutes, Defendants AIG Financial Products Corp. ("AIG-FP") and American International Group, Inc. shall produce the following categories of documents from AIG-FP's electronic document management system, to the extent such documents exist and can be identified by conducting a reasonable search, by March 15, 2011: (1) all 1987 ISDA Master Agreements and schedules thereto; (2) all 1992 ISDA Master Agreements in which the parties selected "First Method" close-out and schedules thereto; (3) documentation reflecting any modification to the close-out provisions of the agreements identified in (1) and (2), whether through subsequent amendment or the transfer of outstanding transactions to a more recent ISDA Master Agreement; and (4) documents concerning the invocation of Section 6(e)(i)(1) of the 1987 ISDA Master Agreement or the First Method of the 1992 ISDA Master Agreement, or information concerning the invocation of any Bankruptcy Event of Default under any ISDA Master Agreement. (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 3/3/2011) (lnl) (Entered: 03/04/2011)

Original Docket Text: DISCOVERY ORDER: As to the first group of requests, counsel have engaged in a vigorous debate, by letter, concerning the degree to which the events of default under different ISDA forms are the same or similar. For present purposes, I will assume that these events of default are identical. Notwithstanding that assumption, however, Brookfield is correct that the business decisions it may have made with respect to other counter parties is of marginal, if any, relevance to the issues in this case. Moreover, the burden that would be imposed by responding to the requests is clearly disproportionate to any limited light that the discovery materials might shed on those issues. The request is therefore denied. Turning to the second group of requests, AIG seeks to establish that certain actions that it took with respect to collateral calls and foreign exchange transactions shortly before the Government bailout were consistent with industry practice, rather than having been occasioned solely by its own dire financial straits,. In an effort to do so, it has requested materials concerning Brookfield's dealings with other parties for a period of many months. This request is overbroad. Brookfield will, however, be required to produce any materials responsive to these requests -but only for the period from September 10 through 17, 2008, and an additional agreed one-week period earlier in time: If the parties cannot reach agreement on a suitable one-week period, the Court will make that selection for them. (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 6/24/2011) (jpo) (Entered: 06/27/2011)

Original Docket Text: DISCOVERY ORDER: that in its letter dated December 8, 2011, plaintiff Brookfield correctly observes that during a discovery conference on November 22, 2011, I reserved decision with respect to its request for the production of the transcripts of all depositions taken in the securities class action pending against AIG in this Court. As I observed during the conference, both sides' arguments have some merit. Recognizing that, I will strike the Solomonic balance that I previously suggested,by requiring AIG to produce the transcript of any deponent in this case who previously was deposed in the class action at least one business day before the deposition is scheduled to occur. If AIG has claimed confidentiality in the SEC action with respect to any of the transcripts or portions thereof, Brookfield shall ensure that the testimony is accorded the same level of confidentiality in this case. Also, because document discovery in this case has been extensive, AIG need not produce the deposition exhibits, with the exception of any resumes or curriculum vitae of the deposition witnesses that have not previously been produced. (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 12/12/2011) Copies Sent By Chambers and Via Fax. (pl) Modified on 12/13/2011 (pl). Modified on 12/13/2011 (pl). (Entered: 12/13/2011)

Original Docket Text: ENDORSED LETTER addressed to Magistrate Judge Frank Maas from Richard F. Ziegler dated 2/24/2012 re: I write promptly to correct Mr. Pickhardt's statement in note 1 that "We understand Brookfield to have challenged only the redactions of statements pertaining to Mr. Cohen's advice and have accordingly limited our submission to those portions of the redactions." ENDORSEMENT: I have not received AIG's letter, which I assume is because it contains highly confidential material and is being delivered by some secure means. Nevertheless, I believe my order was clear, although I neglected to provide a deadline. So that there will be no further ambiguity, AIG is directed to provide me with redacted and unredacted copies of the Entire Board minutes of 9/16/2008 by noon on 2/28/2012. Additionally, if AIG has concerns about this directive, they will need to seek a stay from Judge Gardephe. The mere filing of an objection will not operate as a stay of this order. (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 2/24/2012) (rjm) (rjm). (Entered: 02/27/2012)

Original Docket Text: DISCOVERY ORDER: I have reviewed in camera the materials submitted to me by Mr. Ascher relating to meetings of the Brookfield and Bryson boards, and direct that the items that are set forth in this Order, be disclosed to the defendant. Additionally, I have reviewed the November 1998 "Summary of AIG Swaps." Although that document may have been given to Mr. Bennett in order to educate him about the 1990 swaps so that he could provide legal advice, there is no indication that it was originally prepared for that purpose or at his request. Indeed, the most that Brookfield has been able to represent is that it is "highly likely" that the summary was given to Mr. Bennett. This is insufficient to establish that the document is protected by the attorney-client privilege. The summary consequently must be disclosed to AIG in its entirety. (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 5/4/2012) Copies Sent By Chambers. (pl) (Entered: 05/07/2012)

As a result, on November 21 we requested and AIG agreed that we could serve our responses by noon today (November 26). Accordingly, Brookfield respectfully requests that Your Honor endorse nunc pro tunc today's agreed-upon deadline, with which we have complied. ENDORSEMENT: Approved. ENDORSEMENT: The Court will hold a telephone conference to discuss this issue on 4/23 at 10 a.m. Plaintiff's counsel should initiate the call. Original Docket Text: ENDORSED LETTER addressed to Magistrate Judge Frank Maas from Brian J. Fischer dated 4/17/2013 re: We represent the plaintiffs ("Brookfield") in the above-captioned matter. We write regarding our letter to Your Honor dated April 16, 2013, regarding disputed terms of an agreement the parties reached earlier this year that was intended to resolve a discovery dispute. Following our submission of that letter to the Court, the parties conferred and have resolved this issue. Accordingly, we request that the Court disregard the April 16 letter and cancel the informal conference now scheduled with Your Honor for April 23, 2013, at 10:00 a.m. ENDORSEMENT: Done! (Signed by Magistrate Judge Frank Maas on 4/17/2013) (djc) (Entered: 04/17/2013)

Original Docket Text: ENDORSED LETTER addressed to Judge Ronnie Abrams from Richard F. Ziegler dated 7/9/2013 re: Now that my colleague Jacob Tracer has accepted a clerkship with Your Honor beginning in 2015, I'm writing to seek the Court's permission to let Jake continue to work for a little while longer on the matter this firm is handling that is on Your Honor's docket (Brookfield Asset Management, Inc. et ano v. AIG Financial Products Corp. et ano., 09-cv-8285). ENDORSEMENT: In light of AIG's consent to Brookfield's request, Mr. Tracer, whose clerkship will commence in the fall of 2015, may continue to work on this matter through the submission of the parties' summary judgment motion papers. (Signed by Judge Ronnie Abrams on 7/11/2013) (lmb) (Entered: 07/11/2013)
